properties.grant_description: American Farmland Trust owns Cove Mountain Farm near Mercersburg, PA where they demonstrate grass based dairying on a scale, which relates to the size of most family farms.  Much research is taking place on this facility including design of the milking parlor; research by ARS (Agricultural Research Service) on water onto the farm underground, and water quality into the stream.  AFT believes that dairy grazing is an economically viable alternative for dairy farmers throughout the northeastern U.S.  This grant is to support the cost of a low cost pump and irrigator that is used to spread livestock wastes and milking parlor effluent, evenly over grazing fields.  This installation follows several years of testing the system above ground.  The farm is host to about 6,000 visitors per year.
properties.project_name: Cove Mt Farm Pump & Irrigator Sys
properties.grant_name: Cove Mountain Farm Pump & Irrigation System

properties.grant_description: The Coal Run sub-basin to the Casselman River provides one-third of the AMD into the Casselman.  The Metro discharge is the largest contributor to this loading.  Restoration of the entire 47 miles of the Casselman is the goal of this watershed group.  The PA Fish and Boat Commission have provided documentation of reduced aquatic taxa in the watershed, and the Bureau of Abandoned Mine Reclamation is a partner in the design and construction of the large SAPS, which is the preferred treatment system.  Utilizing a DEP "in-lieu-of penalties" worth $175,000, work has begun on the restoration of this important watershed.

Having received a Growing Greener grant representing 75% of the cost of a $55,000 project, this grant is to provide the balancing 25%.  The removal and regrading of the Mather coal refuse pile is the goal of this reclamation project and a side benefit is that a municipal refuse dump is being removed in the first phase.  Aloe Mining Corporation has agreed to process up to 500,000 tons per year of the screened coal refuse through its Dunkard Mining Company Preparation Plant.  Disposal of the rejected material will not be returned to the site.  Partners include the Izaak Walton League, the PA Fish and Boat Commission, Morgan Township and DEP.  This is a follow up grant to the group, which is addressing AMD on Whiteley Creek, funded by the Program.

There are four types of TMDLs (Total Maximum Daily Loads) into streams in Pennsylvania: point source, non-point source, abandoned mine drainage, and complex.  The TMDL process, federally mandated, will require permitted discharges and non-point interests to carefully assess the implications of the TMDL initiative on their respective operations.  Implementation of a TMDL may include both mandatory and voluntary efforts, such as reduction of permitted discharges, initiating BMPs and or providing financial assistance for pollution abatement.  Because of the complexity of this issue and the process, and the misinformation that is being discussed in the public arena, it was felt that the timing was right for such a conference.

The Scott Conservancy is the sponsor of the Scrubgrass Run Acid Mine Drainage Treatment System.  This group is in receipt of a large Growing Greener grant for this site.  On site technology called the Maelstrom Oxidizer was installed in 1999 and has dramatically improved the efficiency of the precipitation of iron.  This experimental system is needing enhancement due to the lack of land area for treatment of AMD.  This is not a completely passive treatment system and the grant is made conditionally on the commitment to pay for utility costs (O+M) on the part of the Conservancy or the Township in which the treatment system is located.  The students from Chartiers Valley High School are doing water testing for this project every week and further testing is being done by the National Energy Technology Laboratory, (US Department of Energy).  These efforts are to track improvements in water quality on a regular basis.
properties.project_name: Remediation & Improvement of Scrubgrass Run AMD Treatment Sy

properties.grant_description: The request to the Program was much greater than this grant.  However, a small grant was awarded to Sewickley Creek Watershed Association so that they would be encouraged to find the funding needed from other resources.  The project includes a large-scale removal of iron oxide, which has built up at this site over many decades.  The intent is to clear the site of this iron, loose it to a market through the concept of Resource Recovery, rather than hauling it to a landfill.  The next phase of remediation at the Lowber Site is to build a large-scale SAP system.
properties.project_name: Lowber Iron Oxide Recovery Project with Hedin Environmental
properties.grant_name: Lowber Iron Oxide Recovery Project with Hedin Environmental

properties.grant_description: The headwaters of Slippery Rock Creek were documented in 1970 during Operation Scarlift (state funded inventory) as having the most severe condition of coal mine drainage. Indeed, very little drainage from the region does not have contact with coal or coal refuse.  The Argentine Gob pile is the number one priority for restoration as determined by agencies and the watershed association.  The project includes the removal of about 150,000 cubic yards of coal refuse in eight piles in the headwaters of the main branch of Slippery Rock Creek.  Much of the material lies within the creek and forms banks of the stream.  Erosion is prominent and adds to the siltation of the stream.  Monitoring of aquatic life and the re-vegetation of the riparian area is part of the plan.  The overall restoration project is to exceed $1 million.
properties.project_name: Argentine Gob Pile Removal with Stream & Riarian Buffer Rest

properties.grant_description: Drainage from the old McIntire mine site is the source of the worst degradation to Blacks Creek.  At the source of the drainage, the quality of the water is so poor that the effectiveness of implementing current passive treatment technologies would be too costly and sludge removal would become a maintenance problem.  The alternative design is to treat water from an existing sediment pond using a vertical flow pond in combination with settling/flush ponds and aerobic wetlands.  Utilizing a series of alkaline recharge pools is part of the process.  The plan calls for the reconfiguration of the stream channel to approximate pre-mining conditions.  Once complete, the goal is to replant using native species along 1600 feet of stream.  The overall acreage improved is 15 acres of mine land returned to wildlife habitat.  A consortium of local business leaders have pledged support to this $73,000 project.
properties.project_name: Blacks Crk Rest. Area, Slippery Rock Cr Watershed Headwaters

properties.grant_description: In partnership with DEP and the Knox District Mining Office, the Slippery Rock Watershed Association is restoring a gob pile known as SR81 Barren Spoil Area.  The site is on State Game Lands and areas around it have been reclaimed primarily through replanting.  Soil amendments are necessary at this site which is an old surface mine.  The creation of a small naturally functioning wetland is part of this design.  The removal of 2000 cubic yards of mine refuse is the first step in the process.  Approximately one acre of the site requires a fabricated soil mix of spent mushroom compost, and composted biosolids.  The cost of the project is $179,000 and the end phase calls for it to be mulched and seeded for wildlife habitat.  Butler County commissioners have pledged funds to the project as well as the traditional agency partners.

The purpose of this grant is to provide the Conservancy with funding to convene and facilitate a conservation vision for this important series of lakes and dams which, through their efforts and through a large grant from the DCNR land acquisition fund, have recently been put in the public domain.  Partners to be included are Allegheny Watershed Network, Pennsylvania Environmental Council, staff of the Program, the Studio for Creative Inquiry, CMU, and the Center for Watershed Stewardship, Penn State University.

As a result of the success of the first phase of riparian restoration, the Conemaugh Valley Conservancy will treat and plant the remaining 2-mile section of the R+P Trail, along the Loyalhanna Creek and the Conemaugh River.  Secondly, the project will work the same treatment along the Borough of Saltsburg property including River's Edge Park and Canal Park.  In cooperation with the Kiski-Conemaugh Stream Team and their interpretive signage, education about invasive species will take place.  An herbicide called Sharpshooter is being used to compare with others used in the past.  The Program received research on the generic name of this product, called Glyphosate through Penn State's herbicide profile program.  It is determined to be benign except in large quantities to in stream life, which was a concern of the Board of Advisors.  Replanting of the site will be done with native species only. The US Forest Service is the primary funding partner in this project.

Methodology for this stream restoration is being provided by the US Fish and Wildlife Service based upon the principles of natural stream and channel processes.   Watershed level data, forest cover, soils, geology, and topography have all been considered in the design so as to anticipate future channel adjustment trends.  The restoration involves the use of natural materials such as boulders, logs, and live stakes to ensure a natural appearance and an aesthetically pleasing project.  The use of riprap is not a part of the design.  Riparian planting is the second phase of this project and the group is using all native species for plant material.  Located near the town of Entriken, the restoration site is 2000 feet of publicly owned property.  Tatman Run holds the designation as a High Quality stream for its reproducing walleye and smelt populations.
properties.project_name: Stream Restoration & Fish Habitat for Tatman Run, Huntingdon County, PA
properties.grant_name: Stream Restoration & Fish Habitat for Tatman Run

properties.grant_description: Friends of the Riverfront have had a highly publicized success in the replanting of the riparian area along the Three Rivers Heritage Trail.  Using native species only (a condition of the Program's previous grant), the group is now implementing the second phase of this very visible site.  Utilizing over 250 volunteers from public service organizations to environmentally engaged employees of corporations, Friends of the Riverfront is adding signage to the project.  This grant leverages one from Alcoa Corporation and in fact, staff members of the project are serving as consultants to other corporations with property on the river.  Expansion of the project includes sites on Pine Creek in Etna, a new trail near South Side Riverfront Park, Baldwin Borough and the Allegheny Overlook.

The Program has been in a mode whereby it has funded the start-up costs of county chapters of PA CleanWays and this grant is only part of those costs, which approximate $22,000 per county.  Part of the cost is for Board development, staff development and liability insurance for all concerned parties including volunteers.  The vested counties in this case are Bedford, Elk, Greene, and McKean.  Some of the county groups have already completed countywide inventories of dumpsites.  Impetus to each chapter is provided by a variety of individuals including county commissioners, sportsmen, recycling coordinators, farmers, and students.  Since most illegal dumps are streamside, the potential for water quality gains is great.
properties.project_name: Elk, Green, Bedford & McKean Countys Chapter
properties.grant_name: Elk, Greene, Bedford & McKean Countys Chapter

properties.grant_description: This watershed association has been working sequentially downstream on Yellow Creek.  There are five major sites of mine discharges and spoil piles which also create acid mine drainage, along Yellow Creek.  The Program has already participated in the funding of the first phase of this multi-year clean up.  This second phase is several hundred thousand dollars and the project was a recipient of a $200,000 Growing Greener grant.  The passive treatment system installed is part of the effort to reclaim over 2.5 miles of a cold water fishery.  The first phase was funded by 319 NPS grants.  Reclaiming the land includes the removal and burning of the coal refuse piles at a Co-Gen plant, which is located nearby in Ebensburg.  The group has produced a well-designed didactic board, which explains the process of remediation and lists the funding partners. Reconstruction of a wetland is also a part of the phase one design and is now providing a clarifying function.

Earth Force is a national organization created in 1994 through a grant from the Pew Charitable Trusts.  This was because of two emerging trends nationally; young people's overwhelming desire to act on behalf of the environment and their desire to help their communities through voluntary service.  This chapter of Earth Force is located in Erie, PA and their specific project is to install filters in the community's storm drains on parking lots in order to assess the contents of substances, which make their way to the drains.  An eighth grade class is leading this work.  Funding partners are not the usual ones and include the PA Coastal Zone Management, the Erie Co. Health Department, the Pennsylvania Sea Grant, and the PA Steelhead Association.  Letters of support were very compelling.

The project is a 90 acre abandoned strip mine about two miles west of the town of Mapletown.  The discharge point is a four-inch pipe of water flowing at the rate of 23 gallons per minute into a failed sediment pond.  The treatment system is a pair of SAPS or Successive Alkalinity Producing Systems, which fit well on the site.  Many times there are constraints to a sight due to acreage, proximity to a stream or slope.  In this case there are few constraints.  Partnerships are the traditional ones including BAMR, and the local Conservation District office. The sight is located 30 miles upstream from the Monongahela River and remediation will allow further stocking of fish on the part of the PA Fish and Boat Commission as well as improved water quality in the Monongahela. Several streambank fencing and riparian planting projects are taking place in this Greene County watershed.  It is of interest to the Board of Advisors to be working in this under-served region.

The Loyalhanna Watershed Association is participating in the aluminum collection project, which is being lead by Damariscotta.  Some years ago it became apparent to the staff of Damariscotta that the SAPS installed on discharges with high aluminum content, were being plugged up with aluminum or aluminum oxide.  This phenomenon has led to better monitoring on the part of watershed association members.  Also, it created the opportunity to collect this metal and sell it.  With design changes, a select few discharges, high in aluminum content, are being re-designed so that the collection process is easier.  Damariscotta has a customer for this AMD produced aluminum, (ALCOA), and this grant was made so that Loyalhanna Watershed Association could join the group, which is participating in the larger project.

Mountain Watershed Association has been addressing AMD issues in the watershed for a number of years.  They were strong advocates for the release of the AML money in Washington D.C.  With 600 members, this watershed association has been very effective in accessing funding for SAPS designs and the removal of large spoil piles to Co-Gen Plants.  In this case the Gallentine site is a large flow discharge with a pH of 4.0 and the design calls for a APLAPS or a Alkalinity Producing Limestone Activated Pond System.  Following the treatment system will be a polishing or settling basin and a compost wetland.  This project is funded through 319, BAMR, NRCS, and the local Municipal Water Authorities.

Utilizing 319 funds, the watershed association is involved in negotiating purchase of a 75-acre in holding in the middle of Forbes State Forest from New Enterprise Stone and Lime Company.  New Enterprise has submitted an application for a permit to quarry in this area. Secretary Oliver of DCNR has pledged a Keystone grant toward this project and for the Program.  This falls under the category of preservation of a watershed. Recently, the Western Pennsylvania Conservancy gave an abandoned rail bed to this organization, which is a link between the Indian Creek Valley Hike and Bike Trail and the Department of Forestry Trail. This trail land may continue to be held by the watershed association while it is the intent to have the in-holding donated to the State Park system.

PEC, POWR, WPWPP, WPCAMR, and Penn State's Center for Watershed Stewardship are collaborating to put on the second statewide conference on Abandoned Mine Lands and Acid Mine Drainage.  Following the successful first statewide conference, it was decided to have the second one at the Penn State Conference Center and to emphasize a different set of concerns, including maintenance and stewardship of a treatment system as well as discussion of the various permitting processes required by the state agencies.  Funding partners include the DEP and other agencies.  Over 200 participants last year indicated the need for this second conference.

The Southern Alleghenies Conservancy and CTC are the lead organizations in the Resource Recovery movement.  They were sponsors of the Resource Recovery Conference at UPJ last year, where technologies for metals separation were demonstrated from around the world.  Continuing this process, a grant was made to SAC for the convening of the steering committee, and interested parties such as the membership of the Western Coalition for Abandoned Mine Reclamation.  Davis Technologies of Virginia has a hopeful separation technology, which uses a "flocculant" to send sludge upward in the water. Other separation technologies have produced sludge at the bottom of the treatment system, which is still 90% water.  The Davis Technologies sludge has much less water in content.

The Alliance is initiating experimental plots of riparian plantings approximately 600 ft. long each.  The types of buffers installed are Floristic Shrub Buffer, to provide income through the sale of cuttings such as Pussy Willow, Elderberry, Red Osier Dogwood; Warm Season Grasses/Ornamental Grasses, which can provide income through hay/forage or grown for the garden trade; Herbaceous Buffers such as teasel, wild flowers, raspberries and blueberries; Hardwood Tree Buffers, using fruit trees and Hickory and Black Walnut trees.  The unique approach of this grant is to not only plant a riparian buffer for nutrient uptake and improved water quality, but to provide some added benefit through the sale of a marketable product from the riparian area.  The Alliance for the Chesapeake was the lead non-profit in setting the criteria for the DEP Program called STREAM-RELEAF.  This large scale initiative is the state program which is part of the mileage which was committed on the part of Governor Ridge, known as "2010 by 2010".  This three state commitment refers to planted miles of stream, which are to be planted by that date.

Ducks Unlimited has targeted central and western Pennsylvania as their new national emphasis, as a region and are implementing several riparian fencing and planting projects for nutrient uptake and habitat for waterfowl.  The group calls this project Clean Water PA, and Peter Niedbala, the director, is working closely with a Pennsylvania biologist David Wise.  Already, 11,000 acres have been restored to natural habitats in Pennsylvania.  This is a part of the over 1 million acres which have been restored by Ducks Unlimited in the U.S.  Of primary concern to the organization are the migratory species of wood ducks, mallards, teal and black ducks.  The interest on the part of the Program is the improved water quality, which comes with the restored riparian areas. While this is a large grant for the Program, the leverage factor is good as the total cost of the projects is $208,625.  Landowner costs are at 25% and these western Pennsylvania installations are a good counter balance to the USDA-EQIP practices, which are all focused on the Chesapeake Bay watershed, which is in the eastern part of the state.
properties.project_name: Riparian & Wetland Sites in Western PA
properties.grant_name: Riparian & Wetland Sites in Western PA

properties.grant_description: POWR has been awarded at large Growing Greener grant for communications through the WEB based GreenWorks system, set up for videography through DEP.  The Western Pennsylvania Watershed Protection Program has been asked to provide our roster of restoration and preservation projects to be WEB cast.  Participation in this project is consistent with the newly written Strategic Plan and the grant was made to assist in the purchase of the equipment to produce the programming, which will also be documentation of Program work.

This stream restoration project is a 1,700-foot site (1/3 mile) of Blair Gap Run within the Duncansville Borough's Municipal Park.  The project will utilize bioengineering techniques to restore various sections of the stream and to protect other regions from erosion and scouring.  Donna Fisher of the Blair County Conservation District Office is the project leader and flooding in the park has been an ongoing issue.  The use of some riprap is a part of this design.  The project is consistent with restoration efforts, which are ongoing in the region to address the Beaver Dam Branch Act 167 Management Plan.  This plan provides a larger context of the project.  This sub-watershed was a candidate for a Keystone project of the graduate students from Penn State University's Center for Watershed Stewardship.  Native species are to be used for plant material. There is a ball field in the park and there was concern that this project be a water quality improvement and not just the preservation of the ball field.

Working with the Conservation District Office, the SAC staff and faculty of the Juniata Valley School District are restoring a functioning wetland and at the same time creating an opportunity for an outdoor learning center.  Engineering work is underway on recently purchased land to install a swale, leading to the wetland, which will cut down on sediment loadings into the stream.  Agricultural tile removal is a part of this design, and there is an existing dump, which will need to be removed.  (The local PA CleanWays chapter has already made a site visit.)  The reconstructed wetland will be used as an outdoor learning center for teaching environmental studies at all grade levels as the district is a campus of two schools--upper and lower--covering all grades K-12. The Juniata Valley High School Ecology teacher, Mike Smith has served as project leader and plans call for the teaching of plant and animal species identification as the project moves into riparian planting phase. This wetland development project is from the Juniata Clean Water Partnership, Rivers Conservation Plan.

ALLARM is a well-known and respected service provider for water quality monitoring and testing. Working with staff from the Western Pennsylvania Conservancy, located in the project area, ALLARM is providing technical review and support for a watershed assessment of the Ridge and Valley Steamkeepers, working in the Sideling Hill Creek watershed.  Sideling Hill Creek and Town Creek are two of the most pristine streams in the Chesapeake Bay drainage basin.  Both streams and their riparian areas are rich in special plant and animal habitats.  They are host to many rare, threatened and endangered species.  However, both streams are threatened by non-point source pollution from agriculture and forestry.  The greatest threat of all is fragmented development, which is moving in this direction. This is primarily a preservation of a watershed type of project.

Powdermill Nature Reserve is seeking funds to treat additional discharges along Laurel Run through the grounds of the Reserve. This field station is known world-wide for its bird banding and education projects and has banded an average of about 10,000 birds annually since 1961. Powdermill's bird-banding database currently contains over a half million records representing almost 200 species. Since these discharges are downstream from the Friedline Mine treatment system and mostly underground, the technology to be used is limestone dosing of the stream.

The Juniata Clean Water Partnership is a Chesapeake Bay Foundation sponsored regional watershed group covering a 3300 square mile area.  The primary purpose of the Partnership is to provide leadership through the DCNR's Rivers Conservation Program.  Having been successful in receiving the planning grant, the group is now conducting their second round of public meetings in order to prioritize and fund restoration projects in the watershed.  As a clearinghouse, and regional partnership, the group is providing many forums for local officials such as township supervisors to collaborate and learn from the Partnership and one another.  Their intent is to have a Watershed Summit, in the fall in order to convey the message of the Partnership and to teach the public how to form a watershed association, and how to implement a project.

Having participated in the past in the design phase of this large AMD discharge located close to the town of Nanty Glo, this grant is for the purpose of the construction phase.  Previously, our grant went to the Conemaugh Valley Conservancy and since it is a US Army Corps of Engineers project, a 25% match is necessary.  For the design phase, the match needed was 50%.  This particular discharge is one of the major contributors of AMD into the Kiski-Conemaugh River Basin.  The discharge in fact pollutes approximately 50 miles of stream before it flows into Conemaugh Lake.  The Webster Mine Discharge has been the subject of over two decades of water quality monitoring and is listed on the Resource Recovery report of the 101 worst discharges in the western part of the state.  The design is for an expanded version of a SAPS (Successive Alkalinity Producing System), which would be lined and would cover approximately 19 acres.  The site will also require the removal of a coal refuse pile.  Construction will also include 16 additional acres of ponds, wetlands, and required monitoring facilities.  There is an opportunity with this construction to change the character of an entire community toward a better environment.  This could turn into a $3 million installation.

EASI has a grant to form a county citizens volunteer monitoring chapter in Indiana County, PA.  During a site visit, I was able to meet a Senior Corps group, which were called out to provide DEP with some water quality data at a site where training is done for fire fighters.   Chemicals are used in this process, but should be used away from the stream and adequately cleaned up after a training maneuver. They were able to demonstrate their protocol on site and then were able to report the data onto the EASI web site.  As is thought by DEP and the Board of Advisors, it is this reporting system, which is the competitive edge, which EASI provides among the various service providers to citizen volunteer monitoring groups. DEP is a funding partner to this group and the hope is that their Internet expertise will provide base-line data for restoration and preservation projects in the future.

The Pennsylvania Environmental Council is supervising the Alliance for the West Branch as they conduct a Rivers Conservation Planning Grant through DCNR.  These regional watershed groups conduct public meetings to address preservation and degradation issues.  Prioritization is a significant part of the process as those sites, which appear in the plan, and are the only ones eligible for state restoration funds.  Also, it is necessary to have over a 50% sign on to process by the municipalities in the watershed.  At 4,000 square miles, the West Branch regional watershed is one of the largest in the state.  The area is mostly forested, rural and in the Commonwealth, managed by DCNR as state forests and parks. Many of the areas are impacted by AMD and inadequate wastewater treatment systems.  Partnerships include the Audubon Society, USGS, the Anderson Creek Watershed Association, Kettle Creek Watershed Association, Clearwater Conservancy, Pine Creek Protection and local Trout Unlimited chapters.  The budget for this process is very lean but with the help of PEC, should be successful.  Each of these regional watershed organizations act as incubators for restoration projects.

Through a donation of a 7-mile stretch of abandoned railway, along the Conemaugh River, the Conemaugh Valley Conservancy has the goal to eliminate an invasive species called Japanese Knotweed.  As a demonstration project on a large scale, the goal is to replace this plant with native species of trees and shrubs.  Partners include Penn State's School of Forest Resources, DCNR, and the US Forest Service.  CVC has been awarded a US Forest Service grant for Urban and Community Forestry.  A variety of AMD remediation projects along the Conemaugh River have enabled CVC to pay attention to these long stretches of stream in need of improvement, which will decrease sedimentation and improve water quality.  This group is closely tied with the Kiski-Conemaugh Alliance, one of the first regional watershed groups to have completed a DCNR Rivers Conservation Plan. Water quality monitoring will be needed, as the eradication process for the Knotweed requires a pesticide.

This project is for development of a riparian wetland adjacent to a forest buffer in the Muddy Run watershed.  Muddy Run is a small tributary to the Juniata River and the sub-watershed encompasses approximately 1500 acres with the majority of the watershed in suburban development.  Partnerships are strong in this project including the Conservation District Office, Juniata College, the Conservation Club of the College, Southern Alleghenies Conservancy, and the Middle School, which was a recipient of the Governor's Award for the Environment.  This Middle School will provide the team for water quality monitoring after installation.  A request for an easement or a letter of intent from the President of Juniata College was made by the Board of Advisors due to the necessity of buy-in on the part of the College's maintenance department.

This is a streambank stabilization and riparian planting project to eliminate a large sedimentation problem in a watershed.  This remediation is part of a larger vision for restoration, which includes water quality monitoring, and the pinpointing of separate technologies to treat AMD in the watershed.  As a newly formed organization, it is felt that with the guidance of the Conservation District Office, the group will be encouraged by the completion of a successful project.  Though the project is not large in scale, there is some symbolic value in that the site they are trying to protect is close to the Borough waterline.  Survey and design have been going on for some time and partners include PEMA, FEMA, DEP and NRCS.

This grant is for the purpose of watershed preservation in Centre County along Black Moshannon Creek.  Located only 15 miles from the rapidly growing region of State College, this tributary remains a high quality cold water fishery.  Several groups including the Western Pennsylvania Conservancy, the Northcentral Pennsylvania Conservancy, PA-DCNR, Centre County, Black Moshannon State Park and Black Moshannon State Forest have advocated the protection of a significant ecological area of riparian land known as the Snow Shoe Tract.  This 1300-acre tract is being purchased through grants from the DCNR-Keystone Land Trust, the R.K. Mellon Foundation, the Centre Community Foundation, and the Hamer Foundation.  The cost of this purchase and recording fees is $385,000 and perhaps the most significant part of the purchase is an eight-mile long easement along a riparian corridor located in Snow Shoe Township.  Long-term goals include trail development and public access for recreation, but our interest is in watershed protection.

Mountain Watershed Association is using this grant for a site-specific remediation project called Sagamore.  This AMD pollution is one of a series of discharges, which the group has taken on using EPA 319 funds and NRCS Rural Abandoned Mine Program.  The very large SAPS (Successive Alkalinity Producing System) is costing $290,000.  There have been cost overages due to the need to remove additional coal refuse piles.  Allegheny Power has been a partner and they made a contribution toward the overage through their corporate Environmental Stewardship Program.  Our funds will go toward final phase of work which includes the planting and grading of an old refuse pile next to the stream and the Indian Creek Valley Biking and Hiking Trail.  The sequential treatment of 11 AMD discharges taken on by Mountain Watershed Association will remediate 95% of the problems in the Indian Creek watershed.  This is a high visibility area along Rt. 711 leading to Fallingwater, Ohiopyle State Park and Bear Run Nature Preserve.

Following the precedent set in the past; the Board of Advisors has chosen to fund the start-up costs of a county chapter of PA CleanWays.  Money for start-up, in this case, approximately $32,000, goes for the purpose of liability insurance, machine hire, and staff time, should the group decide that paid leadership is necessary.  Small businesses in the community are providing matching funds and this volunteer organization fights illegal dumping/littering and organizes cleanups offering formal adoptions of roadways, waterways and trails.  PA CleanWays also assists in maintaining an area after cleanup and are involved in public education programs.  The group also lobbies for adequate anti-dumping legislation.  A dedicated Board of Directors, on a county basis, is the key to success for individual county chapters.  This seems to have been developed in Blair County. Donna Fisher of the Blair County Conservation District office, also a local farmer, has provided exceptional leadership in site-specific dump cleanup.

Having an already established chapter, Westmoreland County chapter is receiving this grant for the purpose of a specific cleanup in Derry Township.  This proposal is a deviation from the norm for the Program for the reason that we have funded start up chapters and not specific projects.  While we did not originally fund the Westmoreland Chapter, which was the first chapter to be organized, the Board decided that this small grant would be an encouragement to them on this site-specific work. The Derry Township site has much trash, litter, furniture, and auto parts; so much in fact that it extends down a streambank, across the stream and up part of the opposite bank.  High waters will pick up trash and deposit it into a wooded area downstream.

In conjunction with a Heinz Endowments grant to the Sand County Foundation to set up Quality Deer Management Areas this grant was made to provide support for a state wide conference on the over population of white-tailed deer.  The Sierra Club, the Audubon Society, and the Western Pennsylvania Conservancy are sponsoring the conference.  The Sand County Foundation grant pertains to the regrowth of our state forests under DCNR, which are conditionally certified through third party certification and will not be recertified until they address the deer issue as it relates to regrowth.  The grant for the conference is for the purpose of including more of the public, such as the hunting population, environmentalists, managers of public and private lands, and to relate this issue to watershed planning and ultimately improve water quality.  Each of the named non-profits are contributing like funds.

The objective of this grant is to verify that watershed restoration funds being spent on SAPS (Successive Alkalinity Producing Systems) is being done in a cost effective manner and to determine the true costs of operation and maintenance. As background, in the Mill Creek watershed alone, 58 project sites are installed or proposed at this time.  Small watershed associations in charge of operation and maintenance need protocols and strategies to reach their goals of watershed improvement.  Damariscotta, as one of the original designers of SAPS proposes to contact and select 12 representative projects and they will type them for quality and quantity of discharge, and document changes in water quality that have occurred over time.  The grant requires that a comprehensive report be prepared for each project and that a guidance document describing necessary management activities.  The grant leverages $3,500 in in-kind services and accompanies a $7,000 grant from Canaan Valley Institute.
properties.project_name: Damariscotta Acid Mine Drainage and Passive Treatment System Maintenance
properties.grant_name: Damariscotta Acid Mine Drainage and Passive Treatment System Maintenance

properties.grant_description: Hollow Oak Land Trust was approved for this grant for the purchase of the McCormick property, a 160-acre parcel adjacent to several hundred acres already owned by the land trust. Although funding was secured through the Keystone Land Trust Grant Program, the real-estate transaction fell through.  At the last moment the seller decided that his property close to the Pittsburgh airport was worth twice the money. At the time of this event the check had not been written to Hollow Oak Land Trust.  Subsequently, Hollow Oak Land Trust and the Montour Run Watershed Association received conformation that they are recipients of a DCNR Rivers Conservation Planning Grant.  As part of this process Hollow Oak has the opportunity to purchase a linear stretch of land along a riparian corridor owned by the Pittsburgh and Lake Erie Railroad.  For this purpose of land purchase and administrative cost the grant was made in June 1999.  This grant is consistent with others made for the purpose of watershed preservation.

The national organization of Trout Unlimited, as well as the Kettle Creek Watershed Association is determined to tackle several large AMD impacted sites in cooperation with the Office of Surface Mining and the PA DEP.  There are ten major discharges in the lower part of this cold water fishery and they are around the confluence of several tributaries to Kettle Creek.  Working sequentially down from the headwaters, the plan is to determine remediation technologies to be installed, which could approach several million dollars.  This grant is for the first phase of this watershed effort.  Once complete, this project will restore an entire watershed.
properties.project_name: Kettle Creek Watershed Acid Mine Drainage Remediation
properties.grant_name: Kettle Creek Watershed Acid Mine Drainage Remediation

properties.grant_description: The University of Pittsburgh at Greensburg received this grant for riparian replanting to extend and complement the stretch of stream already being addressed by the Sewickley Creek Watershed Association.  Having observed the work of this volunteer group, the Environmental Club on campus and the Environmental Science course taught on campus want to install an on-site example of stream restoration.  Slate Run is a second order stream in the Sewickley Creek drainage basin and flows through the center of the campus of the University of Pittsburgh at Greensburg.  The surrounding drainage basin land use can best be described as residential.  Previous studies of water quality in Slate Run have found moderate water quality as compared to a reference stream.  This project is a good example of good work being observed and another project coming on line.  The one concern for this project is that the maintenance department of the University be brought into the process.

Covering approximately, 250 square miles within Allegheny and Washington counties, Chartiers Nature Conservancy was established to protect the Chartiers Creek watershed.  The creek flows through several heavily populated Pittsburgh suburbs and the group wishes to preserve the greenway status of much of the length of the stream before its empties into the Ohio River, only one mile from Pittsburgh's Golden Triangle.  This confluence is thought to be an invaluable natural corridor for wildlife migrating between the Ohio River and rural Washington County.  The project includes biological inventory work as well as large debris removal, streambank stabilization, and riparian planting, using native species.  A professional naturalist from Chatham College has been retained to conduct the assessment and natural inventory.

The Western Pennsylvania Watershed Protection Program awarded a grant for funding of the wetland phase of a major acid mine drainage problem in the town of Vintondale, Cambria County.  The large discharge, which is visible from a rails-to-trails project, is to be remediated largely through an EPA Sustainable Challenge Grant, which has been secured.  The site plan includes a park area and the imaginative concept of a litmus garden.  The constructed berms, which will slowly pass acid mine drainage from one cell to another, are to be planted with successively acid tolerant plant material.  The town and the site sit literally in the shadow of a spoil pile, which is also contributing to the acid in the stream.  There is a significant intent to provide historical interpretations along the site to provide background information on this pilot project.  EPA has awarded this site a grant of $250,000. This is an example of cooperative grant-making as this project received funding from the Heinz Endowments-Arts Program.

ClearWater Conservancy has a committee, which is charged with the project entitled, "Saving a High Quality Cold Water Fishery from the Effects of Rapid, Watershed-Wide Urbanization."  This stakeholder-based initiative is to promote actions that enhance the quality of life, the environment, and the economy throughout the watershed.  Money was awarded for the startup costs of a basin-wide network of monitoring stations.  The long term stream flow and water quality data generated from these stations will provide regional rivers support groups, including non-governmental organizations and local governments, with the information needed to bring about sustainable development practices in the Spring Creek watershed.  The total cost of the project was $60,000 with much participation from industry as well as the Centre County Community Foundation.

The latest proposal asks for $20,000 to fund two more sites in western Pennsylvania, namely in Allegheny and Butler counties.  The Allegheny site for EASI is to be operated and managed by Vintage, Inc. under project director Marilyn Crouch-Kraitchman.  Work is to be done in conjunction with the Nine Mile Run Project-another Heinz Endowment grantee.  Another monitoring site is on Brush Creek in northern Allegheny County.  An additional 20 senior volunteers will be trained.  DEP has awarded them a total of $250,000 in 1998.

Under the category of grants made for the Resource Recovery initiative, this mini-grant was made for the purpose of the recovery of iron oxides from polluted coalmine drainage.  This grant accompanies a regional Ben Franklin Technologies grant for the same purpose.  This advertised part of the Western Pennsylvania Watershed Protection Program has been the impetus for many inquiries.

This group of elderly Chapter members spent 14 years completing a SAP (Successive Alkalinity Producing) system along Cold Stream at a cost of $327,000.  This passive system is well designed and was funded in large part by DEP and the Chapter was a nominee of the Three Rivers Environmental Awards.  This grant was awarded to assist them in their next project, which is aptly named Chiller Theater.  There are 3 main seeps at this site, which have caused all of the vegetation in the area to die and to be covered by a black, wet slime.  It is estimated that this large passive system in the headwaters in the watershed may cost as high as $900,000.

Friends of the Riverfront, in cooperation with the City of Pittsburgh and the Redevelopment Authority, was awarded $20,000 for their project, "Riverfronts Naturally".  The City of Pittsburgh owns the site and it sits along the Three Rivers Heritage Trail.  It is a destination point anchored at one end by Herr's Island Bridge trail link to Washington's Landing.  The City of Pittsburgh plans to use this project as a model for natural riverfront planning and planting along stream and trail corridors in the city.  Friends of the Riverfront have provided volunteers for cleanup in the past and are part of the remediation process.

Mountain Watershed Association was funded $15,703 for a stretch of 125 ft. of stream bank, which needs to be stabilized and planted in the Indian Creek watershed, Westmoreland County.  The area is a prime fishing site and stabilizing the bank will prevent sediment from washing into the stream.  It is also adjacent to an old railroad bed that will be used for an interpretive trail and nature reserve.  The destabilization at the site has already eroded nearly half of the old rail bed.

The Huntingdon County Conservation District, NRCS, Huntingdon Borough, the Pennsylvania Game Commission, the Juniata College Conservation Club, and the Huntingdon Middle School were funded to restore a stretch of Muddy Run at three sites below the campus of Juniata College.  The use of mixed species along with a few specimen trees is part of the plan.  There is the need for bank stabilization using rock and geotextiles.  Some of the labor and equipment for this purpose is being donated.  The goal of the coalition is nothing less than the complete restoration of this small watershed.  Huntingdon area Middle School received the Governor's Award for the Environment this fall.

PA CleanWays and the Sewickley Creek Watershed Association were awarded $10,000 in funds to clean up two streams in Westmoreland County-one in Hempfield Township and one in Sewickley Township.  One site has an accumulation of litter, daily trash, auto parts and appliances.  The area is along one-quarter mile of stream with a fairly steep embankment.  The other site is a more difficult task as there is a much larger and more concentrated accumulation of trash located over a very steep embankment.  The dump is comprised of numerous piles of shingles, household appliances, construction waste, and tires.

The Blacklick Creek Watershed Association is located in Cambria and Indiana County and was an outgrowth of the Trails Council, which wanted to address horribly, degraded conditions in the watershed.  This passive treatment system will reclaim over 2.5 miles of stream.  The design is complex due to an existing refuse pile.  The construction of a SAP system is combined with an expanded wetland area of over 2.3 acres.  The total cost of the project is $156,000 and monies from EPA and the Pennsylvania Fish and Boat Commission and DEP's 319 monies have been leveraged.  This watershed association is well known for its large numbers of volunteers providing in-kind services.

EASI received this grant for the purpose of training volunteers in water quality monitoring at five targeted sites in the following four counties: Indiana, Indiana County; Meadville and Cambridge Springs, Crawford County; Pittsburgh, Allegheny County; and Warren, Warren County.  The goal is to have 200 volunteers trained by the end of the year.  Training will include not only protocols in water quality testing but in the use of EASI's web based data entry.  EASI is a catalyst for seniors to provide leadership and expertise in solving local environmental problems through existing community organizations.  Currently, the groups use HACH kits and test for nitrates, pH, alkalinity, oxygen, total phosphate, and sulfate.  There is a benthic macroinvertebrate checklist.  This grant leverages a $100,000 grant from DEP.

Headwaters Charitable Trust presented the Program a multiphase proposal for the construction for SAP (Successive Alkalinity Producing) system in order to reestablish a trout fishery in the Clarion River Watershed.  Under PL566, construction funds up to two million dollars have been approved.  Also, $133,000 was approved through the State's 319 program.  Our participation is in the construction and monitoring of two passive treatment systems on Mill Creek and two on Little Toby Creek.  These were the highest priority projects in the proposal.  We have had demonstrated success working with this group.

This grant was made for the construction of three SAP systems on tributaries of Indian Creek.  The sites are located in Fayette County along the route leading to Ohiopyle State Park, Fallingwater and Bear Run Nature Preserve.  It was thought by the membership of the watershed association that the high visibility of the projects would have statewide significance serving as a model for other watershed restoration efforts.  Indian Creek itself is a cold-water fishery further down stream.  The total cost of the project is $290,000 and our funds are being used to leverage 319 money, RAMP money and is partnering with bond forfeiture.  Total removal of the aluminum and acid is possible on this project.  This project is an example of collaboration as in the past; this watershed association had previously been confrontational.

Illegal dumping is highly visible and in the news in the City of Pittsburgh.  The state office targeted Allegheny County for a start up chapter.  A recent donation of $2,000 was received so as to leverage these start up funds and begin a cleanup.  DEP and the City of Pittsburgh would be funding partners in this chapter and citizens of Homewood are the volunteers.  As is the case with these grants, most of the leverage comes from volunteer hours rather than large agency funded grants.  Because of the mission of this Program, targeted and prioritized dumpsites slated for cleanup are streamside.

Angelo Ciotti, an international artist and plants-man is supervising this phase of the project.  Vegetation for wildlife and the control of surface runoff is part of the plan.  Overall, this has been a $400,000 remediation effort on a 500-gallon per minute discharge. NRCS and the Somerset County Conservation District Office have been the lead agencies.  The Board required that the plant material on this site be native species.
The tree planting was done on Oven Run Site F. Students from the Art Institute of Pittsburgh assisted with tree planting.

Through the Katherine Mabis McKenna Foundation, the grant was made for the purpose of streambank stabilization and replanting beside the campus of Westmoreland County Community College.  A list of 29 native species was provided and will be used at the site.  Topsoil was needed as well as streambank stabilization and the goal of shading the stream to decrease temperature should be achieved.  This is one instance where the Board decided that the requested amount ($5,000) was not enough to achieve the goal and more funds were provided.

This grant is for the purpose of installation of more rotational grazing systems on farms with livestock.  It is estimated that the amount of soil saved from entering the stream is 1.3 ton/acre/year.  The average size of the grazing system per farm is 42.5 acres.  Currently, on a county basis, $8,000 is awarded and County Conservation District staff, along with NRCS staff determine, which one or two farms per county per year will participate.  There is a cost to the landowner, being 23%.  The EPA grant, which this grant leverages, is $161,000.  Stream crossings and water gaps can be the landowner's cost-share.  Agricultural BMPs provide an inordinate amount of results in terms of reducing non-point source pollution.

The goal of this project is the complete restoration of the Babb Creek Watershed.  While we were given project locations A thru F, the Board chose to fund a SAP system at the Bear Run Mine.  The Babb Creek Watershed is located entirely in Tioga County in north central Pennsylvania, approximately 50 miles northwest of Williamsport.  At Blackwell, Babb Creek joins Pine Creek at the southern end of a one thousand foot deep gorge known as the Pennsylvania Grand Canyon.  The Grand Canyon itself is a registered national natural landmark.  Babb Creek's acid mine drainage is the only significant pollution source in this watershed.  Other funders include EPA, DEP, DCNR, Orvis Company and the Babb Creek Trust Fund.  Our funding is approximately 10% of the total budget.

This program provided funding for planning grants for small watershed associations under DCNR's Cold Water Heritage Project.  The projects that were identified for funding are: 1) Laurel Hill Creek preliminary assessment by the Somerset Conservation District.  The location of this project is on Jone's Mills Run and Blue Hole Creek.  2) The South Sandy Creek preliminary assessment by Oil Creek Trout Unlimited.  This project is located in Franklin, PA, and some benthic study work has already been done.  3) Rairigh Run planning grant by Grant Township.  This project is located in Indiana County where dirt roads and AMD are impacting a wild trout stream.

This non-traditional grant was made to the Pennsylvania Organization for Watersheds and Rivers for the purpose of leveraging a like amount from the William Penn Foundation.  This statewide organization should be viewed as the state chapter of River Network.  Recently POWR has developed a more proactive board of directors which is participating on a higher financial level of contributions; e.g.. George Martin Foundation, $5,000.  Established in 1993, POWR's mission is to protect, enhance and advocate sound management of our Commonwealth's rivers and watershed systems and to empower local organization with the same commitments.  The "State of Rivers" report is one of their valuable products.
properties.project_name: Initiatives for Pennsylvania Watersheds and Rivers
properties.grant_name: Initiatives for Pennsylvania Watersheds and Rivers

properties.grant_description: Of a total cost of nearly $300,000, traditional wetlands at four sites will be reconstructed or improved.  The purpose of the project is water quality in lake Raystown.  Located on the Raystown Branch of the Juniata River, this U.S. Army Corps of Engineers project is five miles above the confluence of the main stream of the Juniata River.  Previously, these areas were decimated for agriculture use under the guidelines of government programs.  This past practice failed to view the importance of wetlands in improving water quality, reducing the effects of droughts and floods, and providing nesting and breeding habitat for wildlife.  This very public area was seen to be an opportunity for education.
properties.project_name: Raystown Lake Wetlands for Life Project
properties.grant_name: Raystown Lake Wetlands for Life Project

properties.grant_description: This grant was made to leverage other funding for the purpose of producing start-up kits in the target county of Indiana.  There has been considerable media attention to illegal dumping in that county and to the work of PA Cleanways.  There is a tremendous amount of trash lying in and near our waterways.  Litter is everywhere and some areas are plagued with large amounts of illegally dumped trash.  County-based Chapters have identified between 75 and 200 dumpsites in their counties.  One survey showed that 50% of the trash was next to or in a waterway.  There seems no lack of volunteers for this group and they continue to work with other Program grantees.  The start-up kits costs $22,000 per county, and while this leverage is not as great as other grants made, the work of PA CleanWays is admired by all Board of Advisor members.

The Sewickley Creek Watershed Association looks to restore Jack's Run which flows through the heart of Lynch Field within the boundaries of Greensburg, PA. Lynch Field is a high-use recreational area with many sports and exercise activities. SCWA has a well thought out plan to begin short-term, practical projects such as stream bank stabilization, stream side enhancement, riparian buffer areas, and public awareness activities.
properties.project_name: Jacks Run at Lynch Field Restoration
properties.grant_name: Jacks Run at Lynch Field Restoration

properties.grant_description: This grant is for the purposes of water monitoring and was directed for use in training within the geographic boundaries of the Kiski-Conemaugh Alliance.  The Program administrator, R. John Dawes, guided this work.  These past two projects are to enhance the DCNR River Corridor Study so as to qualify that watershed for restoration grants.

This grant was made to raise the pH of Shreve's Run.  Having been impacted by acid mine drainage, this small tributary is near the town of Riddlesburg and is located near the place where the counties of Bedford, Blair and Huntingdon come together.  An important aspect of this proposal is the fact that a larger remediation at North Point is covered 70% by Section 319 Funds and 30% by DEP's Bureau of Abandoned Mine Reclamation (BAMR).  However, BAMR will provide project support for the North Point project only if the Shreve's Run project is addressed.  The grant requested is a good example of Program funds being used to leverage larger funds from other agencies.

This grant was made to assist with the DCNR Pennsylvania Rivers Conservation Program.  Although outside the normal funding activity of the program, it is contingent on CVC working with another grantee, the Alliance for Aquatic Resource Monitoring (ALLARM) for the purpose of training citizen volunteer monitors in unassessed watersheds which are a part of the territory of the DCNR grant.
This grant was for supplies for the continuation in the design of another Successive Alkalinity Producing system on a tributary to the Clarion River.

Along Shaw Run in Blair County, on the grounds of the Bellwood Water Authority is an abandoned mine site that had surface restoration, which did not work.  In conjunction with the Blair and Cambria County conservation districts and the Southern Allegheny RC&D Council, a partnership has been formed to reconstruct the remediation of the site and its discharges.  Dead zones exist among the replanted areas and part of the proposal is for the revegetation of this area.  Ironically, down stream is a public water supply for the municipality of Bellwood.
For supplies only for the expanded budget and costs related to the Friedline Mine project.

A multi-year remediation of Monastery Run has leveraged many hundreds of thousands of dollars.  The acid mine drainage seeps, which are located on the campus of Saint Vincent College, have provided work-study programs for the biology department for a long time.  The design of wetlands, Successive Alkalinity Producing System and other treatment systems is almost complete. Creatively, this treatment system is named the 
"mesocosm." The money from the Western Pennsylvania Watershed Protection Program is being used for the completion of a design to remediate a borehole discharge, which is located next to the stream and is a high flow, high-pressure discharge.  The design calls for the water to be sent back to the first treatment cell through a pipe, and the pressure is such that it is not likely to freeze, even though it is above ground.
properties.project_name: Loyalhanna Creek Watershed, Monastery Run and Fourmile Run Remediation

properties.grant_description: The Sewickley Creek Watershed Association has requested a multi-year grant for the restoration for Jack's Run, which flows through the heart of Lynch Field, Greensburg, PA.  Five Thousand Dollars of this grant was provided the McKenna Foundation.  These funds were for the specific purpose of streamside planting.  This stream flows parallel to Route 119 and is degraded by two known mine discharges located in its headwaters near the old mining town of Bovard.  This grant represents the second payment; the first year expenditure was $8,060 for the quick start remediation projects - all of which were completed.

This joint project is called "Project Grass" and is for the purpose of providing a demonstration site for rotational grazing systems.  Project Grass addresses the issues of nutrient loading and agricultural surface runoff.  It was initiated in Southwestern Pennsylvania and our grant will greatly expand their vision and goals.  This grant provides the local match required for the EPA funded grant, which is in the amount of $150,000.  Cost share programs for farmers and livestock raisers need to be lower cost to the farmer as that segment of the economy is marginal in the best of times.  Agricultural runoff is the second largest water quality problem in the western part of the state, after AMD (Acid Mine Drainage).

This is a streambank stabilization project along a very visible part of Spring Creek in Centre County.  In fact, it is at the site of the Boalsburg Museum and Memorial - the home of Memorial Day.  This well publicized environmental association has garnered many partners for the restoration for this stream.  The total cost of this restoration at the Pennsylvania Military Museum is $73,745.  Native species are being used in the planting phase of the project and many volunteer hours have been garnered by the project.  This grant represents approximately 14% of the cost of the project.  Many volunteer hours have gone into this project.

This project at the Heidekat Two Mine in Franklin Township, Westmoreland County, has been a difficult design for Rural Abandoned Mine Program and the NRCS.  This project is part of an overall watershed approach to clean up which includes limestone diversion wells at Export and Murrysville.  These limestone beds, diversion ditches, and French tile drainage systems are to be located on private lands, demonstrating local citizen participation.

This grant is to support the Pike Run Watershed Project contingent upon review of how personnel costs will be financed in future years.  There is a good plan to not only fence off streams but to actively restore the riparian zones to a state where there is demonstrable bio-diversity.  This is being done through the use of warm season grasses and other plant material.  This co-operative effort with landowners has a track record and is administered by California State University.  Again, this is a unique approach to restoration of a watershed.  Funding partners include the Pennsylvania Game Commission, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and the University.  Total budget is $150,000.

This grant was made to support the completion of the cleanup at a site called Brandy Camp in the Clarion River basin.  This very large underground discharge varies from 500 to 1,000 gallons per minute.  A passive system is to be installed as follow-up to a multi-year study using a flow meter, which has been monitoring the discharge.  This is a follow-up investment on our part having already participated in the construction of two demonstration sites in the watershed.  The goal of this group is nothing less than the complete restoration of the Clarion River.  No award of grant monies for their communication efforts was made.  (This is the site of the Heinz Endowments' staff visit in the Fall of 1996.)
This grant was for land purchase of 29 acres conditional upon commitment of Key '93 monies. This is a corridor project located between Moraine State Park and McConnell's Mill.

This grant is to support the cleanup and filming of three waterway sites of debris.  Each of the sites has a different component and the video produced is to make the viewer aware of concerns and hazards involved in the cleanup of illegal dumps.  Susan Wiseman is the leader of Pennsylvania CleanWays and this organization is a good example of a grassroots effort toward improving the environment.  Heinz Endowment staff requested a meeting in Pittsburgh, in order to secure an interim grant for the purpose of strategic planning for this organization.
properties.project_name: Black Lick, Sewickley & Dunbar Cr Cleanup Video

properties.grant_description: This grant is directed toward the cleanup of the Arnot 2 mine discharge #4 along Babb Creek.  This is the last main pollutant and finalizes the watershed restoration in this area.  The funding partners are The Bureau of Mining and Reclamation, DEP, and of course, the applicant.  Again, the use of a SAPS system and an Anoxic Limestone Drain leading to a natural wetland will restore the condition of the stream.  A unique characteristic of the design is a hydraulic head, which with adjustment will accommodate variable flows.  This region is located 50 miles north of Williamsport in the area of Pennsylvania's Little Grand Canyon.  Total budget is $162.000.
properties.project_name: Babb Creek Rest. Arnot 2 Mine Disccharge #4
properties.grant_name: Babb Creek Rest. - Arnot 2 Mine Discharge #4

properties.grant_description: Pre-approved Fall '95. Aeration of the discharge was determined to be an important technology to improve effectiveness of this treatment system. A baffle design was donated by a regional company called the Bayer Corporation.

This grant is to leverage much larger funds from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, the Cambria Co. Commissioners, the Conservation District, NRCS, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, and others for the cleanup of the Webster Mine Discharge at Nanty Glo.  This huge flow of 400 to 1,000 gallons per minute is to be treated with a SAPS system (Successive Alkalinity Producing System), which would be larger than any which has previously been constructed.  This is a first bold step in the cleanup of 200-point discharges along the Conemaugh River.  It is also the greatest pollutant to Conemaugh Lake.  Our grant is to leverage $393,000 in federal and local dollars.  Another $10,000 has been pre-approved for 1997 for phase two of the project, depending upon progress of the project.

This cleanup of the Wilson Run mine is to be done over a three-year period at approximately $10,000 per year.  1996 was pre-approved based upon a progress report, which was very well done.  The technology used is a semi-passive treatment for a high flow (700 to 1,400 gallons per minute), alkaline, high iron discharge.  This is a different problem from the acid mine drainage we have funded in the past.  A compressor/static mixer to aerate the water is being installed as well as an aerobic wetland before the water flows into the stream.  A side benefit from a safety standpoint is to close an 8' x 8' airshaft.  There are good partners on this project--OSM and NRCS as well as an excellent staff person Tom Keller.  The maintenance of a treatment system is always a concern and this watershed association has been very diligent in execution and reporting on the project.  Our funding represents 18% of the overall cost.

The Central PA Forum for the Future is a non-profit arm of the SEDA-Cog or Council of Governments.  This group is pursuing a DCNR Susquehanna Greenways planning grant and our funds were part of a local match needed of $45,000.   Including the grant, the Program hosted a local luncheon for philanthropies and leaders in the region.  Extending from its headwaters in Cambria County to its confluence with the Main Stem at Sunbury, the West Branch corridor has been a focus of the WPWPP.  This river corridor is one of five such regions being established to facilitate citizen and local county government involvement in a regional planning process. GIS compiled maps are being used on the nearly 500 river miles with the hope of emphasizing water quantity and quality, natural, and cultural development strategies.  William Penn Foundation is a partner is this process as well as the first phase of the DCNR grant which is $300,000.

This grant is for the start up of another county chapter in Venango County.  Formed in Westmoreland County in 1990, PA Cleanways has 16 chapters that are actively and methodically cleaning up illegal dumpsites, most of which are streamside.  Our Program grants have already gone toward the start up of eight chapters.  Only one has not been continuously successful and that is the Pittsburgh chapter.  Program grants are for liability insurance and cost incurred for kits which provide instruction as to how to begin a chapter.  Funds are also used for the first cleanup site.  In this case, the first site to be tackled in Venango County is within 50 feet of a stream.  Our grant leverages an additional $44,000 from DEP and from the statewide office which has a three year decending grant process.

Wells Creek Watershed Association was formed in 1999 by local citizens to address AMD in Wells Creek, Somerset County, a tributary to the Stonycreek River.  Wells Creek enters the Stonycreek upstream of the 6 site $5 million Oven Run Project.  Although the discharges on Wells Creek do not eliminate aquatic life in the Stonycreek they do not provide the quality of water that should allow for the full recovery of the Stonycreek River.  The discharges on Wells Creek are coming off of the DCNR Kiski-Conemaugh River Basin's River Conservation Plan.  The group is in receipt of a Growing Greener grant for the design of the treatment system.  The proposed design is a large scale SAPS which will impact and improve an existing wetland.  Because of the wetland, the permitting process has been lengthy.  This grant is for on the ground construction costs only.  Above the discharge on Wells Creek is a reproducing trout fishery.

This grant is the first of two years work in planning for the protection of Lake Pleasant.  Located in the headwaters of French Creek, this watershed supports 24 plant species and two animal species that are rare, threatened or endangered in Pennsylvania.  The Western PA Conservancy considers Lake Pleasant to be one of our highest priority biodiversity sites in western Pennsylvania.  The financial needs to accomplish this assessment were only partially met by a Growing Greener grant.  Immediate threats to the lake include invasive species of plants, non-point source pollution and the removal of large quantities of sand and gravel in the watershed.  Though small, this 64 acre watershed contains a wide diversity of organisms of special concern and Program guidelines refer to working on an eco-system basis.  The variety of partners include DEP, Edinboro University, Allegheny College, Argonne National Lab, Erie Conservation District, PSU, PA Audubon, and DCNR.

The purpose of this grant is to support the closing and recording fees for the acquisition of 78 acres of land in Upper Saint Clair and South Fayette Townships, Allegheny County.  This property is adjacent to Boyce-Mayview and Environmental Educational Center.  It is the site of a highly toxic, abandoned mine discharge and the Program expects to participate in the implementation phase as well.  The acquisition phase cost is $450,000.

The purpose of this grant is for the "Convening Farmland Preservation Program." The staff of the Southern Alleghenies Conservancy invited land-owners and stake-holders to explain to them the need for participation in order to leverage the federal portion of funding for farmland preservation.

Miller Run is a primary tributary to Shoup's Run and its headwaters serve as a water supply for Saxton Borough.  The recommended treatment for acid abatement is In-Stream Limestone Sand Treatment (ILS).  This technology has proven effective in neutralizing acid in small watersheds.  The sand is applied to the stream during low flow months, in August and September.  This ILS site is one of several projects which include a large passive treatment system, being supervised by BAMR, the Bureau of Abandoned Mine Reclamation.  This small treatment system will provide buffering for the entire watershed, which is 4,444 acres.

The Burgettstown Area School District has an outdoor classroom which has been studying the causes and effects of abandoned mine drainage since 1999.  Working in partnership with DEP, the Conservation District Office, and the Racoon Creek Watershed Association, this school district intends to complete the planting phase of an on-site SAPS and settling ponds.  The school was built atop the former Fulton #1 deep mine, which was abandoned in 1922.  Outcomes are AMD abatement and numerous educational opportunities.  Overall cost of the project is $38,000.
properties.project_name: Outdoor classroom on abondoned mine dr.

properties.grant_description: The overall cost of Phase 2B of this AMD treatment system is $241,370.  This grant is a continuation of the funding provided in the Spring of 2001.  Project includes the removal of spoil piles to the co-gen plant in Ebensburg and Program funding will be applied to unanticipated seeps in this Phase 2 project area.

The overall cost of starting up this chapter is $51875.  Over the past several months, efforts to start this chapters have resulted in a one year plan that includes three clean-ups and a full scale, comprehensive education program.  The Beaver County Chapter includes a partnership with Independence Marsh Foundation and they have prioritized several dump sites in Raccoon Creek State Park. PA CleanWays continues to leverage more volunteer hours than any other Program Grantee.
properties.project_name: Beaver County Support cleanups & chapter efforts

properties.grant_description: The overall cost of starting this chapter is $51,875.  Over the past several months, efforts to start this chapter have resulted in a one year plan that includes three clean-ups and a full scale, comprehensive education program. PA CleanWays continues to leverage more volunteer hours than any other Program Grantee.
properties.project_name: Butler County Support cleanups & Chapter efforts

properties.grant_description: Mountain Watershed Association has implemented a high cost, abandoned mine drainage treatment site at Sagamore.  This innovative set of settling ponds drops out hundreds of tons of iron oxide prior to its discharge into Indian Creek.  This grant is for the purpose of design enhancements at the Max B. Noble Mine Site.  $2,000 of the grant was made to provide matching funds for an AmeriCorps position for the Watershed Association.  The total cost of the design enhancements is $58,000.

Formed in 1997, the Three Rivers Habitat Partnership was formed as a regional project of the Wildlife Habitat Council.  Over 1300 acres on 24 corporate sites in the Pittsburgh region have been managed in a natural way by the TRHP.  The purpose of this grant is to garner approximately 100 new landowners to the program and to educate at least 5,000 individuals as to the value of forested, riparian buffers.

The purpose of this grant is to leverage $160,000 from DCNR to form a partnership with Juniata College staff for training of teachers in the newly adopted Academic Standards in Environmental and Ecology.  Waterhseds and the literacy thereof is the first listed academic standard.  Much of the activity will take place at the institution's Raystown Lake Ecological Field Station.  This is a timely project in that the regional watershed association known as the Juniata Clean Water Partnership is moving to this campus at nearly the same time.  There will be many opportunities to implement data into action.

These funds will be used to hire Branden S. Diehl, a Juniata College graduate, as a project manager. The position included: project development, outreach, project oversight, compliance reporting, and overall project management. Projects included: AMD, watertrail and recreational trail development, FE Cooper Superfund site, Potter Creek Assessment, and military pre-deployment training on the Pike to Bike.

The third annual conference on abandoned mine drainage and reclamation was held at the Penn Stater Hotel and Conference Center June1 and 2, 2001.  POWR acted as the conference coordinator and topics included full group participation, interactively with "Where Are We With Technology Today?" Breakout sessions included anoxic limestone drain sizing as well as presentations on new SAPS designs which use a readily available carbon source.  Funding and Implementation were addressed by Dave Hogeman from DEP's Growing Greener Grants Center. Secretary, Dave Hess of DEP was the Keynote speaker.  Presentations were made on the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act, or SMCRA and the future of the AML fund.  A presentation of the Resolution for Re-Authorization was made.

The regional project of the Wildlife Habitat Council is called the Three Rivers Habitat Partnership. Through local watershed, conservation organizations, and private industry, the group supports the installation of natural riparian areas using native plan species for the solution of runoff problems and non-point source pollution abatement. Through a demonstration project, education and outreach, the group aims to educate at lease 5,000 individuals and to garner approximately 100 landowners in the process. Forested riparian buffers provide a variety of functions related to waters quality and aesthetics as well as provide habitat for wildlife. The targeted area for this specific project is southwestern PA along Deer Creek, Pine Creek, and Montour Valley, as well as northwestern PA along the Allegheny River in conjunction with the Forest Service’s Wild and Scenic River program.

Loyalhanna Watershed Association  is in receipt of a farm property on the outskirts of  Ligonier, PA.  This farm known as the Burke-McConaughey Farm is 150 acres of slope pasture, facing south, with a farm house and several farm buildings such as a large barn.  The land adjoins a school house property owned by the watershed association and they are in receipt of a previous grant for this site.  This small grant is for planning purposes to envision the use of the property to demonstrate BMPs or agricultural Best Management Practices.

Mountain Watershed Association has implemented a high cost, abandoned mine drainage treatment site at Sagamore.  This innovative set of settling ponds drops out hundreds of tons of iron oxide prior to its discharge into Indian Creek.  This grant is for the purpose of design enhancements at the Max B. Noble Mine Site.  $2,000 of the grant was made to provide matching funds for an AmeriCorps position for the Watershed Association.  The total cost of the design enhancements is $58,000.

On a 54 acre donated site, Allegheny Township, Westmoreland County is reclaiming a coal refuse pile along Pine Run.  This is seen as an opportunistic grant because the group wished to utilize donated topsoil from a developer, which needs to be done under a timeline.  This township is known for its progressive zoning code which requires any developer to put 30 % of potential developed land into green space.  Total cost of the reclamation is $73,000 and once this is complete, the group intends to implement an AMD treatment system at a cost of $130,000 to bring back to life one mile of stream.
properties.project_name: Reclamation of Pine Run Coal Refuse Pile
properties.grant_name: Reclamation of Pine Run Coal Refuse Pile
