Its applications range from wood stains to concrete color enhancers. This project will further illustrate the beneficial use of iron oxides and show that they have no structural impact on concrete.

The Pennsylvania Environmental Council proposes to prepare a Rivers Conservation Plan for the Catawissa Creek Watershed located in Columbia, Luzerne, and Schuylkill Counties. The Rivers Conservation Plan, through an extensive public involvement process will address environmental, cultural, and natural resource issues within the watershed and make locally relevant recommendations for preservation or restoration of environmental integrity to the watershed based upon public input and information gathered during the course of the project. These plans are essential in order to apply for agency restoration grants.
project_participants: PA Department of Conservation and Natural Resources
Eastern Pennsylvania Coalition for Abandoned Mine Reclamation

properties.grant_description: This grant will contribute to the development of a communications strategy undertaken by PennFuture for the Abandoned Mine Land Fund. The work will include consultation, production of communications/media pieces, and participation in conference calls. PennFuture is strategic in placement of op-ed pieces in Congressional districts throughout the state.

The purpose of this grant is to help offset the costs of extra printings for the summer and fall issues of PA Project Grass 2005 Magazines and the organization's Statewide Conference and Grazing Field Farm Tour.
properties.project_name: PA Project Grass 2005 Magazine and Conference

properties.grant_description: The Friends of Raystown Lake would like to benefit from the help of an AmeriCorps member to support important environmental improvement projects. Among concerns of Friends of Raystown Lake is the overpopulation of deer in the forest around the lake, degrading the understory to the point where there has been a change in tree species. The group is also working on a Chestnut tree nursery in order to provide a site for blight resistant trees in the national effort by the American Chestnut Foundation.

This grant helped Audubon Pennsylvania complete the distribution of “Managing White-Tailed Deer in Forest Habitat and Ecosystem Perspective: Pennsylvania Case Study,” a report of the Deer Management Forum convened by Audubon PA and the PA Habitat Alliance. As Pennsylvania has gone through the lengthy and costly process of having its state forests certified as sustainable, it is important to understand the impacts an over-abundant deer population has on re-growth.

Last year, attendance at the Westmoreland Earth Day reached 2,000 participants. Attendance at this year's Earth Day is expected to increase by another 1,000 participants. This year's event will demonstrate the connections that exist between members of the community and local natural resources.
Grant was awarded for the purpose of reviewing of project specific permitting related to the clean up of Toby Creek.

This award was provided to evaluate seven systems for which the WPWP leveraged money.  The study included evaluation of structural integrity of the systems, O&M, overall operations, chemicals, and macroinvertebrate data collection.  This data was then compiled into a report for the Program and gave an in-depth look into the success of operation of AMD treatment systems.

This on-going preservation effort is planning to begin a sub-set of activities called “French Creek Ecotours."  The intent is to purchase the assets of a local outfitter and to combine the project’s educational activities with recreational opportunities.  The emphasis is quality, not quantity, but nevertheless it is expected to service around 1,000 individuals per year.  A French Creek Sojourn is planned for June starting in Erie County and ending in Franklin, Pennsylvania.  At that point, after traveling over 70 miles, the French Creek joins the Allegheny River and it is here that the PA Environmental Council’s and the Alleghenies Watershed Network will continue an organized float on the Allegheny.   Once again, it is anticipated that the project will work with farmers and landowners to assist in the implementation of BMP’s.  A Growing Greener Grant for $180,000 was received for this purpose.  Activities include streambank fencing and the use of many volunteers for the removal of exotic plant species along the streambanks.

The Southern Alleghenies Conservancy, Canaan Valley Institute, and various small watershed associations are working on a community based site for the composting of livestock manure.  The proposed site is the Morrison’s Cove valley near Martinsburg, PA where several 400 cow dairy herds are located.  With intensive agriculture being regulated by the EPA’s TMDL process, (Total Maximum Daily Loads) there is the need to export nutrients out of certain watersheds.  The idea of the group is to convene the stakeholders and to set up a community site for composting, needing a carbon source from municipal clippings, where the manure could be dried, composted and sold.  In order to comply with current regulations, the composting site must be less than five acres.  The purpose of the grant is to convene the stakeholders.

This project is for development of a riparian wetland adjacent to a forest buffer in the Muddy Run watershed.  Muddy Run is a small tributary to the Juniata River and the sub-watershed encompasses approximately 1500 acres with the majority of the watershed in suburban development.  Partnerships are strong in this project including the Conservation District Office, Juniata College, the Conservation Club of the College, Southern Alleghenies Conservancy, and the Middle School, which was a recipient of the Governor's Award for the Environment.  This Middle School will provide the team for water quality monitoring after installation.  A request for an easement or a letter of intent from the President of Juniata College was made by the Board of Advisors due to the necessity of buy-in on the part of the College's maintenance department.

The Allegheny Mountain Chapter of Trout Unlimited is conducting a bench scale test of a new passive design for treatment of AMD.  This new type of SAPS is to treat a surface mine site on Cook’s Run on PA State Forest land which seeped from an already reclaimed site.  The project was spear-headed by Dr. Colson Blakeslee who was an original founder of PEC or the PA Environmental Council.  This toxic seep has created a dead zone in the forest and is of great interest to the Bureau of Abandoned Mine Reclamation.  Joe Schueck of that section of DEP has written numerous reports on the site due to its unique history and slope.  The plan is to use a mixture of limestone and readily available wood chips in a combined mixture, (rather than in layers) in an anoxic state, for treatment of the water.  Jim Gusek of Knight Piesold, Denver, CO is the consulting engineer and was a recent presenter at the 3rd Annual Conference on Abandoned Mine Reclamation at Penn State.

This proposal will support the completion of the non-point source assessment for Crooked Creek as outlined in the associated Rivers Conservation Plans. The scope of this work was previously approved by the DEP and is a continuation of their funded project. The assessment will look at stormwater, agriculture nutrient runoff, AMD and other sources of non-point source pollution. The previous assessment was consumed by simply documenting the watershed’s AMD impacts. This project is necessary to document additional project needs and will serve as the guiding document for future project prioritization and work plan development. The group hopes to build a watershed restoration strategy from the completion of this plan.

The Cross Creek Watershed Association seeks funding to repair a section of degraded streambank. The majority of the damage took place during the Hurricane Ivan flooding and the area has only continued to erode. The design will incorporate the use of native rock to enhance and compliment the area, while the riparian planting will use vegetation that is native to the area and historically accurate based upon findings of archeological excavations.

The Filson #7 discharge represents the last known major seep in this particular portion of Mill Creek. The discharge currently flows into a constructed pond that drains into a natural wetland. The pond is now filled with sludge which will be pumped from the channel and captured in a Geotube (a permeable sediment collection bag) and analyzed for potential pigment use. The empty pond will be reconfigured as an anoxic limestone drain (ALD). The existing pool area will be expanded to accommodate the required limestone volume for ALD construction. The ALD will discharge to a channel that leads to the existing settling pond which will be double the size of the original. The pond will be constructed to facilitate the removal of iron sludge.
properties.grant_name: Little Mill Creek AMD Redesign and Reconstruction

properties.grant_description: In partnership with local educators, DEP, DCNR, and three at-risk youth groups, Lake Erie - Allegheny Earth Force will conduct a watershed tour. The tour will focus on viewing and understanding a watershed from its headwaters to its downstream reaches. Youth participating in the tour will achieve an understanding of what a watershed is, how it functions and how their actions in it can cause negative or positive impacts. A key component of their understanding will revolve around riparian assessment and will put their new-found working knowledge of buffers to work by implementing a riparian buffer project at the John E. Horan apartments.

The purpose of this grant is to establish the background water quality and quantity at the site of the Botanic Garden of Western PA for a 12 month period prior to a complete site reclamation. This data will facilitate the permitting of a 240 acre reclamation project.

Previous designs and construction at the Gallentine site were left useless after the mine-pool backed-up and blew out. This proposal aims to obtain funding that will support the redesign  of the project and to cover Mountain Watershed Association’s work to acquire additional land easements needed for construction. The Natural Resources Conservation service will provide the overall design for the project.

The North Hills Council of Governments is under contract with the DEP to update the Act 167 Stormwater Management Plans for Girtys Run, Pine Creek, Squaw Run, and Deer Creek watersheds in Allegheny County. The project has several goals, chief among them is the need to improve existing stormwater management and land use ordinances.

The North Area Environmental Council is in the process of developing a Rivers Conservation Plan (RCP) for the Pine Creek watershed. The primary goal of this RCP is to establish a unifying road map for future restoration and protection of the watershed.

The Tireless Project is a five year old collaborative effort of organizations concerned with the quality of life of western Pennsylvanians and the waterways that are Pittsburgh’s focal point for the character and city-life. Program funds are needed to support the only ongoing, collaborative, grassroots initiative to enhance the aesthetic, economic, and health value of Pittsburgh’s rivers by cleaning man-made debris from riverbanks within the Pittsburgh pool.

Program funds will be used to quantify Venango County’s illegal dumping problem and support cleanup and stewardship efforts of the new chapter. Venango has a known illegal dumping problem, but it has not been officially quantified or documented. This baseline is information needs to be generated in order to complete cleanup efforts.

PA Lake Erie Watershed Association and a myriad of project partners have amassed a sizable amount of project funds to address water quality concerns in the watershed. These projects will have a positive impact on the watershed. Little data exists to provide good baseline data on how these projects will improve fish habitat. This request will be used to support a fish study.

An unnamed tributary to the Allegheny River has experienced increased stormwater runoff and associated streambank damage. This project aims to repair a highly eroded streambank, protect a major thoroughfare, and prevent continued sedimentation into the Allegheny River. This grant will be used for contingencies that arose during project implementation.

A unique partnership among the Shade Creek Watershed Association (SCWA), Somerset Conservation District, PACD, NRCS, and the Borough of Central City was formed to implement a treatment system for Reitz #1, the fourth largest discharge in the watershed. Constructed along Laurel Run, the site is readily accessible to the public and is in need of vegetative buffers and interpretive signage. The buffer should diminish the odor caused by the hydrogen sulfide produced in the system’s bioreactor. The signage will ensure that the citizen’s of Central City understand the treatment system and that they can use it as a pubic asset instead of a liability.

The success of the Stonycreek restoration has created numerous initiatives and groups that are committed to the complete restoration of the watershed. The partners in this restoration effort have made a reassessment and reevaluation of the 1996 USGS report a high priority and a necessary component of the remaining restoration efforts. Somerset Conservation District in partnership with local, state, and federal stakeholders need to complete a reassessment and update to the USGS report. Their plan would outline the remaining sources of pollution, quantify improvements, and provide a cost estimate of the remaining work. In the last several years project implementation has slowed because of data gaps and funding shortfalls. This plan will assist the District and PA DEP Bureau of Abandoned Mine Reclamation in future restoration efforts that will include a reassessment of the Quemahoning Creek watershed in order to quantify its improving water quality. This project will create the necessary tool that will enable the many existing watershed groups to leverage the funding required to put additional projects on the ground.

Turtle Creek has few streams that are high quality or exceptional value. Most of the watershed’s streams are impacted by abandoned mine drainage (AMD) with the exception of two tributaries - Haymaker Run and Steel’s Run. Both of these streams are designated as High Quality Cold Water Fisheries (HQCWF). Increased development along Haymaker Run over the past 40 years is causing accelerated degradation. This project aims to protect the HQCWF status of this subwatershed by implementing a natural stream channel design, diverting stormwater and implementing riparian buffer protection plans.

The purpose of this grant is to directly reduce nonpoint source pollution (NPS) in the Sewickley Creek Watershed. Specifically, the Westmoreland Conservation District will use innovative stormwater best management practices at their GreenForge Building and promote effective ways to manage stormwater among those citizens with the most influence to do so.

Increasing development and rainfall intensity have created flooding within the project area. Program grantees/partners are working within the watershed to identify recreational and conservation goals/objectives. The conservation easements held by the group in this area are preventing development and protecting water quality. Several of these parcels are fallowed fields in need of revegetation. There is also a need to promote habitat corridors and suitable habitat for Indiana bats that are present in the watershed.

Wilson College is seeking funding for the enhancement of a nature trail and restoration of Conococheague Creek. In a previous partnership with American Rivers and the PA Fish and Boat Commission, Wilson College demolished two dams which precipitated the need to remove creek obstructions and perform other necessary natural stream channel designs to stabilize the streambanks. This will be a highly visible restoration project for habitat enhancement, open to citizens of Chambersburg, and students of Wilson College.

“Hope for Polluted Waters” will address the impact of abandoned mine drainage (AMD) in Pennsylvania, its influence on waterways and stream life, and on the health of the population. This documentary will tell the stories of individuals and groups engaged in remediating the more than 3000 miles of stream impacted by AMD.

Audubon PA seeks the Foundation’s support to convene partners and share plans for improvements to Audubon the Hawk Watch at Waggoner’s Gap. Improvements include better access and trails, a handicapped viewing area, and more detailed signage to interpret the site.

The Six Mile Run Area Watershed Committee seeks support for their 4th annual Watershed Festival. The festival will bring together environmental groups and agencies, along with the public to celebrate the watershed’s improvements and bring to light the problems yet to be solved.
seller_address: 187 Municpal Rd. PO Box 57, Defiance, PA, 16633

properties.grant_description: This grant will be used to cover the costs of a Regional Conservancy Roundtable that aims to bring together local conservancies in the region to learn about what each group does and explore opportunities for collaboration on common goals.

McCormick Island has many important ecological and natural resource values that can be preserved through its purchase by the Central PA Conservancy (CPC). In order to inform and attract potential donors and stewards, CPC seeks funding to hold an event regarding the acquisition and subsequent protection of McCormick Island.

The US Fish and Wildlife Service has offered to complete Phase 1 of an emergency restoration project on a portion of Wallace Run, a stream with a long history of erosion problems. The Bald Eagle Watershed Association is seeking funding to pay for fuel and geotextiles needed to complete the project.

The 2007 PA Statewide Conference on Abandoned Mine Reclamation is themed “Getting Your Priorities Straight,” with the pun intended on helping watershed and community groups get a handle on the Priority 1, Priority 2, and Priority 3 Sites within their watersheds. EPCAMR is seeking funding to help maximize the conference’s reach to watershed volunteers  by keeping attendance costs low.

The GreenTreks Network is seeking funding to promote the implementation of the DEP’s manual of stormwater best management practices. This effort will help guide municipalities in their attempts to strengthen water quality protection, provide greater infiltration, and improve watershed planning.

The Headwaters RC&D Council is partnering with the regional watershed specialists and watershed associations in their efforts to put on a regional watershed conference. The goal is to help encourage the various organizations to work in a coordinated fashion  while adopting a regional context for projects and programs in order to make better use of existing resources and in developing new ones.

The Shoup’s Run Watershed Association is a finalist for the Western PA Environmental Awards. As a finalist, two complimentary tickets to the event are provided. However, four individuals from the group would like to attend the event and they are seeking funding to cover the cost of the additional tickets.

The Independence Marsh Foundation looks to develop updated organizational program literature and corresponding web pages to define its goals for restoration of the 20-D watershed. This will help demonstrate the organization’s worthiness of public and private support.

The Juniata Clean Water Partnership Sojourn is an educational and fun canoe and kayak journey celebrating the beautiful River, as well as the natural, cultural, and historical resources of the Juniata watershed. This grant will offset the expenses associated with holding such an event.

The Juniata Clean Water Partnership seeks funding to help support watershed awareness within the Juniata River Watershed. The funds would be used for equipment rental to spend a day on the water and show participants the various projects that have been completed or are near completion in the watershed.

The League of Women Voters of PA Citizen Education Fund seeks funding to conduct two sessions related to communicating the message of Water Resources Protection at the upcoming Water Resources Education Network Orientation meeting.

Natural Biodiversity (NB) and the Kiski-Conemaugh Stream Team (KCST) are hosting Outdoor Heritage, the region’s showcase of environmental education. The purpose of this event is to educate student’s in the region about their natural and cultural heritage and to inspire them to take positive action. Since there are no admission fees for the event, NB and KCST are seeking funding to help cover some of the costs incurred for holding the event.

The PA Association of RC&D Councils seeks sponsorship for the 2007 Mid-Atlantic Association of RC&D Council's Annual Conference held, this year, in Grantville, PA. The  conference has been held annually for the past 16 years and moves throughout six states in the region. This event allows the participants to share programs and projects, success stories, and new ideas to improve communities.

PA CleanWays of Allegheny County seeks funding support to host a roundtable meeting to launch a new initiative to “engage and empower people to eliminate litter and illegal dumping Allegheny County.” The meeting would include numerous community groups with whom the organization has worked in conducting illegal dump cleanups, litter cleanups, and for whom the organization has provided technical or logistical support.

Throughout the state, the PA Environmental Council  (PEC) is recognized for its premier environmental awards program. This year, PEC will be partnering with the Commonwealth and the PA DEP in announcing the 2007 Governor’s Awards for Environmental Excellence. PEC seeks support in the form of sponsorship of the event.

The PA Institute for Conservation Education (PICE) seeks funding support to facilitate strategic planning for a new PICE educational initiative - the PA Master Naturalist training program. This program is a national initiative that aims to connect people with their local ecosystems and watersheds through intensive natural science training and local conservation service work.

The PA Lake Erie Watershed Association (PLEWA) is sponsoring a workshop entitled, "Bluff and Streamside Dos and Don'ts." It will focus on best management practices for property owners along Lake Erie bluffs and nearby tributaries. PLEWA seeks funding to support the planning and implementation of the workshop, including mailings, brochures, materials, supplies, tour buses, and boxed lunches.

The Southern Alleghenies Conservancy is creating a fund in memory of Dick Rice - one of its long-standing Board members and greatest conservationists. This fund would support environmental studies or other natural science related degrees at accredited institutes of higher education.

The Penn State Master Well Owner Network (MWON) will be hosting the first PA Private Water Well Symposium. The goals of the symposium are to present the latest research findings related to private water systems, facilitate networking among professionals in the field, and integrate research and educational efforts to promote better management of the private water systems throughout PA. MWON seeks support in the form of sponsorship of the symposium.
seller_address: 132 Land and Water Research Building, University Park, PA, 16802

properties.grant_description: The PA Organization for Watersheds and Rivers (POWR) is embarking on a process to revisit its strategic plan. The purpose of the planning process is to examine the relationship between the funds available to support POWR's efforts and determine whether and how to pursue their mission in a financially sustainable way.

The Rose Valley Mill Creek Watershed Association is seeking funding to hold a watershed festival and fishing derby. This event aims to educate the community about the value of the watershed and ways to protect and conserve its resources.

The Somerset Conservation District will partner with the Somerset County Technical School to establish a program that will allow fast growing poplar trees to be used as a future bioenergy source. The expectation is that this project will also provide an economic source for future scholarships for technical school students.

3 Rivers Wet Weather is partnering with the Local Government Academy, PA Environmental Council, PA DEP, and the Allegheny County Conservation District to sponsor a workshop entitled “After the Storms: Stormwater Management for Municipal Officials." Topics will include stream ecology basics, stormwater impacts, and positive actions being taken by municipalities.

One of Toby Creek Watershed Association’s (TCWA)proudest accomplishments is the Blue Valley Fish Culture Station. This state-of-art facility chemically treats an alkaline discharge and uses the treated water to raise trout. Due to growing interest in the facility, TCWA looks to offer a tour in an effort to educate the public about the process and benefits of treating AMD.
properties.grant_name: Blue Valley Fish Culture Station Tour

properties.grant_description: Trout Unlimited seeks support for the West Branch Susquehanna Restoration Symposium III. The purpose of the symposium is to promote and continue the momentum of the West Branch Susquehanna River Restoration Initiative, which is aimed at the cleanup of abandoned mine drainage throughout the region.
properties.grant_name: West Branch Susquehanna Restoration Symposium III

properties.grant_description: The Western PA Conservancy seeks support for the 6th Annual Westmoreland Earth Day. The mission of this event is to demonstrate the connections that exist between members of the community and local natural resources, including awareness and education of watersheds. About 2000 people attend this event every year.

The DEP, in conjunction with the Citizens Advisory Council, is scheduling a series of public town hall meetings. The topic for the meetings is the recent re-authorization of the Federal Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act (SMCRA). The Western PA Conservancy seeks funding to provide refreshments for ten of these meetings.

This award will cover the costs of the Western PA Coalition for Abandoned Mine Reclamation’s efforts in the Abandoned Mine Lands (AML) Campaign. These efforts include the production of “The Future is Now” DVD and the distribution of AML Campaign letters to all PA legislators.

The 2007 PA Statewide Conference on Abandoned Mine Reclamation is themed “Getting Your Priorities Straight,” with the pun intended on helping watershed and community groups getting a handle on the Priority 1, Priority 2, and Priority 3 Sites within their watersheds. WPCAMR is seeking funding to help maximize the conference’s reach to watershed volunteers  by keeping attendance costs low.

The objectives of the Coldwater Heritage Partnerships Program are: 1) to foster a greater public understanding of watershed characteristics as they affect coldwater ecosystems and 2) to produce preliminary resource planning documents that may lead to full river conservation plans or direct implementation to protect and enhance our coldwater fisheries. This year's awards will support the development of Coldwater Conservation Plans for Brown's Run (Warren County), Fishing Creek and Cedar Run (Centre and Clinton Counties), Hosensack Creek (Montgomery, Berks, and Leghigh Counties), Ramcat Run (Fayette County), Wallack's Branch of Bob's Creek (Bedford County), Waltz and Greenwalk Creeks (Northampton County), and West Branch of Crum Creek (Chester County).

The Chesapeake Bay Funders Network recognized in 2005 that reaching the 2010 goal for removing the Bay from the Federal “impaired” water quality designation cannot be reached without significant nutrient reductions from agriculture. Agriculture is a major component to the region’s economy but it is also contributing 40 percent of the excess nitrogen and 46 percent of the excess phosphorus. This is the largest single sector of nutrient pollution above that of waste water treatment plants and other urban contributions. Despite farmers’ conservation efforts in the past, the future will require, as one state described it, “historic” new efforts in conservation practices. This initiative concentrates on manure and farmer assistance, the two areas believed to be the most strategically significant in terms of achieving agricultural nutrient reductions.

Cedar Run enters the Yellow Breeches 3.5 miles upstream of the confluence with the Susquehanna River. The limestone geology abounds with springs that once made Cedar Run one of the finest trout streams in PA. Despite its urbanized state, studies and personal accounts indicate that it still supports a naturally reproducing trout population. Products of this River Conservation Plan will include a preliminary baseline report compiling existing monitoring, assessment, and land use information for the watershed, as well as a final report detailing field assessment findings, project locations, and implementation recommendations at the subwatershed level.

Encroachment practices along Davis Run have caused significant impacts on conveyance and stream stability. Alder Run Engineering has devised a restoration plan that will address two sections of the stream that are plagued by flooding and erosion.

The League of Women Voters is seeking support for additional consultant work to conduct two sessions related to communicating the message of water resources education and protection at the upcoming WREN Orientation meeting.

The Moshannon Creek Watershed Coalition intends to address the number three and four priority discharges of the Sandy Run tributary to Trout Run. Since these discharges are close in proximity and similar in chemistry, the goal of this project is to have a detailed treatment design that will incorporate both discharges into one passive treatment system. The treatment of these discharges will remove a total of 140 lbs/day of acidity, 5 lbs/day of iron, and 5 lbs/day of aluminum. This improvement will aid the in the restoration of the Sandy Ridge Tributary along with improving water quality in Trout Run as a whole.

The Clearfield Creek Watershed Association has worked diligently to outline the major sources of contamination of Little Laurel Run, a stream that was historically a Cold Water Fishery. This work resulted in a Watershed Restoration Plan that identifies the need to address three discharges impacting the upper half of the watershed.

The Deer Creek Restoration Project at Rolling Hills Golf Course proposes the restoration of a nutrient impaired reach of Deer Creek. The lack of streamside vegetation to stabilize banks has resulted in excessive bank erosion, loss of aquatic habitat and severe sedimentation. The volume and rate of surface water runoff associated with storm events continues to increase, exacerbating the problems. The implementation of fluvial geomorphology and a natural stream channel design will curtail the degradation.

This project will continue the success of measures taken in the Kiski-Conemaugh basin to prevent the spread of invasive species from watershed to watershed. Monitoring of both impacted and non-impacted watersheds are essential to tracking the spread of invasive species. Natural Biodiversity has conducted watershed inventories on many of the headwater streams in the Kiski-Conemaugh an Juniata Basins. Additionally, the project will also support the continued outreach and education classes that were so successful and widely attended in 2007.

The North Area Environmental Council is at the beginnings of the river conservation plan (RCP) for the Pine Creek watershed. The RCP will provide a systematic and comprehensive  assessment of the need for, as well as opportunities for, stream restoration work and recreation enhancement in the watershed.

The Susquehanna Greenway Partnership (SGP) proposes to examine where abandoned mine lands and drainage intersect, overlay, or impact the Susquehanna Greenway Network Corridor. This is an effort to assess the impacts on the Greenway and identify areas for collaborative and holistic approaches to remediation and revitalization of river communities.

These funds will be used for two projects in the Kettle Creek Watershed: KC204 Mine Pool Stabilization & Swamp Area Passive Treatment System. The first project is a mine pool stabilization which protects the lower Kettle Creek and the West Branch Susquehanna River from the impending catastrophic mine blowout of the Kettle Creek No. 1 mine on the west side of lower Kettle Creek. This project has reduced the environmental hazard posed by the collapsed KC204A mine drain in three ways. First, by reestablishing two drains the mine can now drain freely from three locations. Prior to the project, the collapse of the single free flowing drain (KC204) would have led to a dangerous buildup of water within the mine. Second, the reestablished mine drains reduce the likelihood of a mine pool blowout by allowing the mine to discharge greater flows at lower mine pool elevations. In  this way, the probability of excessive mine pool elevations is reduced. Third, since the mine pool is kept at a lower elevation, the total volume of water that could be released if a blowout would occur has been reduced. As a result, the potential damage caused by a blowout is reduced.
The second project will be to design, permit, and construct the Swamp Area Passive Treatment System. This project will address the first major source of AMD to Twomile Run, which is Class A native brook trout stream above the AMD pollution.

This demonstration project in Allegheny County is the first of its kind in the state - to use water from a mine pool as geothermal heating and cooling. This project is part of an effort to reduce abandoned mine drainage exposure in this Herron Avenue corridor of Pittsburgh and is being looked at very seriously by the Office of Surface Mining Bureau of Abandoned Mine Reclamation offices. The project provides an opportunity to build upon and expand this geothermal resource.

The Western PA Conservancy will create a Rivers Conservation Plan for Brokenstraw Creek. The value of the Rivers Conservation Planning process through the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources (DCNR) is that it provides a blueprint for restoration projects within a watershed.
This grant covers the cost of 500 copies of the DVD “Hope for Polluted Waters” to be distributed to PA Legislators to support the Susquehanna River Watershed Project.
properties.grant_name: Hope for Polluted Waters - Susquehanna River Watershed

properties.grant_description: This grant covers the cost of the Independence Conservancy’s time and travel for the testimony at the Office of Surface Mining stream buffer hearing.
This grant will be used to purchase food and materials needed to support the annual Volunteer Appreciation Picnic for the Kiski-Conemaugh Stream Team and Natural Biodiversity.
This grant will serve as sponsorship of the 2007 Mid-Atlantic RC&D Councils Conference.
This grant is intended to bolster the Mountain Watershed Association’s work on the Stream Buffer Zone rule.
This grant will serve as sponsorship of the 2007 Mid-Atlantic RC&D Councils Conference.

This grant is to support the Shade Creek Watershed Association in coordination, facilitation, and participation efforts. In the fall of 2007, Board of Adviser's members toured the watershed to learn more about the innovations of the Reitz treatment system.

The purpose of this grant is to help the Shamokin Creek Restoration Alliance purchase laptop computers needed for pressure transducers measuring flows at discharges and housing of watershed assessments.

This grant will cover the cost of Andy McAllister’s attendance at the 2007 National Association of Abandoned Mine Lands Program Conference in Bloomington, Indiana. It is at these national conferences where innovative technologies in mine reclamation are shared and showcased.

The purpose of this grant is for outreach involving Coal Field Headwaters Protection. Goals for the project include increased public knowledge regarding ecology of headwater streams in coal field areas and mining activities that impact these areas and an increase in interaction among academics, environmental professionals, watershed associations, and public agencies.

This grant will serve as sponsorship for the 2007 Ohio River Watershed Celebration aboard the Gateway Clipper Majestic. This year’s cruise will sail up the Monongahela River. Lectures and presentation on specific policy issues are a part of this event. History of the watershed and the industries it supports is always part of the programming.

The Allegheny Valley Conservancy seeks funding to continue the conservation successes along the Allegheny River. These funds would be used for two land acquisition projects and one significant streambank restoration and protection initiative on Mill Creek.

This grant will be used to convene a larger group of Community Watershed Organizations (CWO) and those agencies that provide technical assistance to them to discuss the various challenges they face including: problems with grant applications and reporting, promoting improved fiscal accountability, building membership and fundraising, communicating with members and others key to achieving the CWO's mission, strengthening community boards and involving more volunteers, seeking more collaborative partners, and other management challenges faced by these often all-volunteer groups. The Bayer Center for Nonprofit Management also intends to build a proposed solution to be implemented by the Department of Environmental Protection.

The Botanic Garden of Western PA would like to host an important Roundtable Discussion featuring U.S. Congressman Tim Murphy and OSMRE Director Brent Wahlquist on the topic of the Appalachian Regional Reforestation Initiative and its potential impact on abandoned mine land reclamation in PA.

This grant would extend funding for a water sampling project started in 2007. Due to heavy rains of late winter, several new discharges appeared on the site that were not there during the original sampling period.

The Buffalo Creek Watershed Alliance of the Merrill W. Linn Land and Waterways Conservancy seeks funding to support its annual audit and associated administrative costs. The Foundation for PA Watershed is known for accommodating organizations that incur unexpected administrative costs.

The Chesapeake Bay Trust seeks donations to support the Chesapeake Bay Funders Network, an organization dedicated to providing opportunities for grantmakers to network, exchange information and partner on protecting and restoring the health of the Chesapeake Bay and its watersheds.

A 2007 Watershed Specialists' Needs Assessment identified that GIS training was a topic for education. This two and a half day applied training is in direct response to that interest. This grant will offset the costs of the  training session at Bloomsburg University.
This grant will support expenses incurred by the Environmental Integrity Project during efforts to secure environmental safeguards for the disposal of coal combustion waste in Pennsylvania.
The Eastern PA Coalition for Abandoned Mine Reclamation is seeking funding for its co-sponsorship of the 10th Annual Abandoned Mine Reclamation Conference.

A tri-county partnership between Crawford, Erie, and Warren Conservation Districts is launching a “Green Tips” television commercial campaign. The overall message and objective of this project is that individual landowners can contribute  to the reduction on non-point source pollution and help improve water quality. "Green Tips" can be found on the web at www.greentipsonline.com.

The Juniata Clean Water Partnership seeks funding to support its 8th Annual Sojourn. This is an educational and fun canoe and kayak journey celebrating the scenic Raystown Branch, as well as the natural, cultural, and historical resources of the Juniata watershed.
The Juniata Valley Sustainability Club requests support for the establishment of a permanent recycling program for the Juniata Valley School District.
seller_address: 7775 Juniata Valley Pike, PO Box 318, Alexandria, PA, 16611

properties.grant_description: The Kiski-Conemaugh Stream Team and Natural Biodiversity are seeking support for their 2008 Annual Outdoor Heritage Festival, the region’s showcase environmental education event. More than 725 participants are expected at this year's event, which will take place at Summer's Best Two Weeks at the Quemahoning Reservoir on April 24 and 25.

The Lake Erie-Allegheny Earth Force seeks funding to support its Community Action and Problem Solving program. This program connects students to real-world environmental issues through training and support of area teachers.

This grant will support the cost of construction materials and labor to restore approximately 100 linear feet of stream bank along Nine Mile Run that was eroded and altered during a high rain event. Project goals include rehabilitating the stream bank, increasing habitat for fish and macroinvertebrates, and providing a unique educational experience to the students of the Greater Latrobe Area School District.

The Keystone Central School District intends to restore four acres of functional wetlands  and the ecosystem function of a five acre upland/riparian area to the Chesapeake Bay. The overall project is intended to support nonpoint-source pollution mitigation while creating a learning environment about watersheds, wetlands, and the ecosystem habitat they provide. As part of the master site plan, a pavilion and walking trail will be constructed to further assist the public in learning about this project and enjoying the overall beauty and function of wetlands.
seller_address: 212 West Kyler Ave., Mill Hall, PA, 17751

properties.grant_description: The Mountain Watershed Association is seeking funding for its coalition work to protect current or upgraded designations of streams.

The purpose of this grant was to develop the preliminary stages of a capacity building program for watershed associations to be administered by the Foundation for PA Watersheds. It is envisioned that this need will be funded by philanthropy and the PA Department of Environmental Protection. The goal is to develop higher quality proposals to be submitted for project implementation grants. .

The Kiski-Conemaugh Stream Team and Natural Biodiversity are seeking funding to hold their 4th Annual Joint Volunteer Appreciation Picnic. This event highlights the organizations' accomplishments, volunteers, staff, and project partners.

Since 1990, PA CleanWays will have properly disposed of 10,000 tons of trash from the Pennsylvania landscape through its grassroots programming efforts. PA CleanWays is planning a dinner that will bring its volunteer network, funders, partnering organizations, and general supporters together to celebrate this accomplishment as well as its founder, Sue Wiseman, who will be presented with the PA CleanWays Legacy Award.

The PA Council of Trout Unlimited is seeking funding to support the Keystone Coldwater Conference entitled Headwater Ecosystems: Protection, Management, and Research. Based on past attendance, it is expected that this event could draw nearly 300 participants. The conference will be held at the Penn Stater Conference Center in State College, PA on February 22 and 23. There will be a workshop on headwater taxonomy and field identification, including hands-on breakout sessions looking at amphibians, reptiles, fish, plants, invertebrates, and mussels common to our coldwater ecosystems. 
This year's keynote speakers, Larry Schweiger from the National Wildlife Federation and Bern Sweeney from the Stroud Water Research Center, will present information about the perils facing our headwater streams, why it is imperative to protect these ecosystems, and what is being done to ensure their long-term health. Eight breakout sessions will cover topics related to the latest research on headwater ecosystems, management tools and techniques for improving watershed health, and methods to best protect these precious ecosystems.
This grant serves as a Bronze Table Benefactor Sponsor for the 2008 Harrisburg Dinner Governor’s Awards for Environmental Excellence.
The PA Land Trust Association seeks support for the 2008 PA Land Conservation Conference aimed at empowering attendees to better protect watershed lands.

"Black Diamonds" is a documentary that highlights coal extraction exploits throughout Appalachia. This grant is part of FPW's ongoing outreach/education aspect of the Abandoned Mine Lands Fund reauthorization. Grant funds will support the dissemination of 20 DVDs of the film to strategic partners throughout the region.

The Penn State College of Agricultural Sciences joins forces with the PA Department of Agriculture and the Penn Sate Institute of Energy and Environment to convene a statewide working conference, Agriculture and Environment: Achieving Balance. The conference is designed to identify new solutions to the old, yet challenging issue of nutrients in the environment. This event is scheduled for June 2 and 3 in Harrisburg.

The Rose Valley/Mill Creek Watershed Association is seeking funding to conduct an annual watershed festival/fishing derby on the Rose Valley Lake. The event includes activities such as watershed awareness, lake habitat and aquatic species education, PA Fish and Boat Commission educational programs, litter cleanup contest, and a cane pole fishing derby.

The Six Mile Run Area Watershed Committee seeks funding to support their 5th Annual Watershed Festival. The Festival will bring together environmental groups and agencies, along with the pubic, to celebrate the watershed improvements made thus far and raise awareness of the problems that remain.
seller_address: 187 Municpal Rd. PO Box 57, Defiance, PA, 16633

properties.grant_description: The intent of the “Building Collaboration for Effective Watershed Stewardship” project is to coordinate 14 established watershed associations in Allegheny County to engage residents and visitors in a better understanding of their responsibility to care for our regional water resources.

Trout Unlimited seeks support for the West Branch Susquehanna Restoration Symposium. The purpose of the symposium is to promote and continue the momentum of the West Branch Susquehanna Restoration Initiative, which is aimed at the cleanup of abandoned mine drainage throughout the region.
properties.grant_name: West Branch Susquehanna Restoration Symposium IV

properties.grant_description: The Washington County Watershed Alliance (WCWA), the Washington County Conservation District, and the Cross Creek Watershed Association have been continually working to restore a portion of stream bank along Cross Creek at the site of Meadowcroft Rockshelter. The goals of the project are: 1) to restore 300 feet of Cross Creek by installing a cross rock vane to direct the flow of water away from the banks and toward the center stream channel and 2) to reintroduce historically native plan species in a riparian area between the stream channel and the parking area.
The Western PA Coalition for Abandoned Mine Reclamation is seeking funding for its co-sponsorship of the 10th Annual Abandoned Mine Reclamation Conference.

The Western PA Conservancy seeks funding support for the 7th Annual Westmoreland Earth Day. The mission of the event is to demonstrate the connections that exist between members of the community and local natural resources. Since the first Westmoreland Earth Day in 2002, nearly 12,000 people have attended this event.

The 7th Annual Earth Day at St. Vincent College is themed “Greening Your Footprint.” The organizers of the event seek funding to be used for tent rentals and to support an alternative fuel vehicle to transport attendees.

The Citizens Coal Council is a coalition designed to galvanize the coalfield justice movement and protect people, land, and water from the harm caused by coal extraction. The group seeks funding to continue their collaborative efforts.

French Creek is among the most ecologically significant and richest waterways in the northeastern United States. It contains more species of fish and freshwater mussels than any other stream in the northeastern United States, prompting one expert to maintain that “French Creek is undeniably one of Pennsylvania’s foremost aquatic treasures.” The Nature Conservancy named French Creek one of its original “Last Great Places,” and considers French Creek one of the thirty most important bodies of freshwater in the United States, Latin America, and the Caribbean. In results from a recent study, French Creek consistently rises to the top of a group of regional watersheds when viewed from perspectives such as water quality and biodiversity.

The Buffalo Creek Watershed Alliance (BCWA) seeks funding for the restoration of Buffalo Creek. This project will include characterization of water quality and flow in the headwaters to determine the level of impacts and required remediation to restore water quality. The plan will also address the evaluation of remediation approaches and the development of a conceptual treatment approach to add adequate alkalinity to the stream in order to mitigate the impacts of acidic deposition. BCWA hopes to move toward the construction of a passive treatment system.

The Agricultural Initiative is working on the watershed level to address Chesapeake Bay water quality through enhancing assistance to farmers to adopt conservation practices and advancing market-based approaches to managing animal waste while simultaneously strengthening the economic sustainability of farming communities in watersheds threatened by land development.

In order to provide leadership among youth and citizens in implementing the Clean Water Act, Environment America is seeking scholarship funding to support a summer internship for a Water Policy Specialist.

Recent increases in development within the PA Route 60 corridor have caused a change in both the amount and timing of flood events that flow through the Raredon Run watershed, a tributary to Raccoon Creek. Four sites within the Raredon Run watershed have been identified for streambank stabilization and/or restoration. Each site has eroding streambanks near homes or roadways and excess deposition of sediment within the streambed that has changed the dimension, pattern, and stream profile. The problems associated with each site are largely caused by a lack of riparian buffers.

The purpose of this distribution is for continued support of the Coldwater Heritage Partnerships program. This year's awards will support the development of Coldwater Conservation Plans for Beaver Creek (Schuykill County), Miller Run (Huntingdon County), North Fork of Powell's Creek (Dauphin County), Paradise Creek (Monroe County), South Branch Little Aughwick (Fulton County), and Stony Run (Chester County).

The Kiski-Conemaugh Stream Team coordinates a volunteer based water monitoring program, provides technical assistance and environmental education, and implements several special projects. The goal of the Stream Team is to engage residents, particularly youth, in restoring, maintaining, and enjoying our natural resources.

The Lower Penns Creek Watershed Association with the Conservation Districts of Union and Snyder Counties have partnered with Susquehanna University and EcoAnalysts, Inc. to assess the main-stem of the Lower Penns Creek Watershed. This assessment will help focus the Association’s efforts by providing usable and up-to-date data that will be utilized to determine priority areas within the watershed and build membership and partnerships.

In October 2006, the Stewards of the Lower Susquehanna (SOLS) and the Lower Susquehanna Riverkeeper began the Conowingo Sediments Outreach and Education Project by bringing together expert scientists who had been studying the problem. Now SOLS must build public and legislative support for funding the research and solutions needed to mitigate the sediment accumulation problems. They plan to do this through public meetings throughout PA and MD, distributing educational handouts, creating websites and video and by continuing meetings with their state decision-makers and other conservation and community organizations.

The Mill Creek watershed is negatively impacted by nonpoint source agricultural pollution. Previously completed streambank fencing has had a positive impact as documented by the PA Fish and Boat Commission - parts of the river now support fish stocking efforts. This project reflects an opportunity to work with traditionally hesitant Amish and Mennonite groups. The overall project intends to continue educational efforts and to install an additional 20,000 linear feet of streambank fencing.

Program funds are needed to support the only ongoing grassroots, collaborative initiative to enhance the aesthetic, economic and health value of Pittsburgh’s rivers by cleaning man-made debris from riverbanks within the Pittsburgh pool. Every year flood waters strew tons of man-made debris along the banks of Pittsburgh’s Rivers. This debris decreases the aesthetic quality and the economic value of the riverfront and forms breeding grounds for mosquitoes and other disease vectors. Goals of the upcoming season focus on completing the inventory that weather prohibited executing last year and working to engage new groups in the program, including recreational river users.

The PA Organization for Watersheds and Rivers (POWR) is seeking funding to pursue a merger with the PA Environmental Council (PEC). Much of the negotiations, including the decision to move forward with this merger, have already been completed. The remaining work involves: changing/formalizing IRS paperwork, consolidating staff, and developing operational budgets. Funding is also being sought to disseminate information regarding SMCRA.

Currently there is no Rivers Conservation Plan for Wills Creek, largely an unpopulated watershed with pristine locations and rugged terrain. Through a joint partnership with Maryland Department of Environment, Somerset Conservation District will work with Maryland officials to modify their stream assessment tool and apply it to the watershed’s headwaters. The preassessment data is intended to lay the framework for a 2010 Rivers Conservation Plan grant submission, and serve as an update to the County's Wills Creek Implementation Strategy.

The Stroud Research Center is seeking funding to assess impacts of acid mine drainage and its remediation on ecosystem structure and function of streams draining to the Chesapeake Bay. The goal of this project is to determine the extent to which AMD impairs streams in order to understand nutrient losses to downstream reaches and the Chesapeake Bay.

The Susquehanna Greenway Partnership is seeking funding to develop and implement land conservation strategies and environmentally sensitive design practices to protect and enhance the natural areas and water resources of the Susquehanna Greenway corridor. The goals of this project are: establish land conservation priorities and partnerships, advocate and promote conservation and environmentally sensitive design, and protect regional priority lands.

WVIA TV seeks funding to help support the development of a DVD entitled “Nutrient Trading: Reducing Pollutants in Our Waters,” which examines the nutrient impacts to PA’s waterways, and highlights efforts, programs, and tools being used to improve water quality. The production will be an outreach and education tolls that will be used for advancing the Nutrient Trading Program.

Capital Resource Conservation and Development Council, Inc. seeks funding to provide administration and project planning/implementation costs for two regional projects. The funds will cover the costs of bringing together and working with the project partners to plan and implement important conservation in the Mill Creek watershed. Additionally, funds will support the application of amended poultry manure for mine land reclamation and biomass production.

Confer Construction seeks funding for a Field Day presentation on requirements for Act 537 implementation for on-lot septic systems in rural communities. Attendees will include staff from the Huntingdon County Conservation District, local township supervisors, and the general public. The goals of the workshop are consistent with the reduction of nitrogen and phosphorus required under the Chesapeake Bay agreement.
Funds were used to pay for preparation for the Huntingdon County Planning Commission and Geisinger Health Care dinner at Huntingdon Farm.
The Keystone Conservation Trust seeks funding to help nonprofit organizations reach qualified donors and explain that they can sell real estate and donate money to conservation at the same time.
seller_address: 336 King of Prussia Rd., Radnor, PA, 19087

properties.grant_description: The League of Women Voters seeks funding to conduct Phase I of a Strategic Program Evaluation for the Water Resources Education Network Project, a program of the League of Women Voters Pennsylvania Citizen Education Fund.

The Stewards of the Lower Susquehanna wish to convene a meeting of chief scientists, economists, and manufacturers that have agreed to review the current information and options available for addressing the Lower Susquehanna River dam sediments and the threats from these sediments to the Chesapeake Bay.

The Mountain Watershed Association seeks funding to continue its work opposing the redesignation of Grinnage Run. The Foundation Coal petition to downgrade four streams within the South Fork of Ten Mile Creek is the second industry-generated petition submitted to the Environmental Quality Board to reclassify streams in southwestern PA.

The Ohio River Basin Consortium seeks funding for its Research and Education Symposium. This event will be hosed by Carnegie Mellon University and will focus on the topic of Urban Water and Watersheds in the Ohio River Basin.

The Pennsylvania Grazing Lands Conservation Initiative (GLCI) is hosting the National GLCI Steering Committee for the annual fall meeting and tour of some of Pennsylvania’s premier grazing operations. In order to achieve a high quality tour and program, GLCI is looking for financial sponsors for this event.
properties.grant_name: GLCI Steering Committee Meeting and Tour

properties.grant_description: The PA Council of Trout Unlimited seeks funding to help with administrative support for the Coldwater Heritage program.

The Roaring Run Watershed Association seeks funding to help generate river data required for their ongoing Energy Harvest Grant Program. The program’s goal is to develop and test a microhydroturbine power generation system that will power an on-site AMD treatment system.

Stream Restoration, Inc. is seeking funding for their 7th Annual Ohio River Watershed Celebration. Due to the overwhelming response, this year’s event has been expanded to include a second boat. The theme for this year’s event is “Innovative Energy for a Green World” and will highlight many points of interest along the Ohio River.

The Western Pennsylvania Conservancy seeks funding to provide support for convening a group of twenty conservation and environmental organizations across the state to plan for a significant funding campaign. Based on initial meetings, the new funding campaign will provide financial resources to programs now being funded under the Growing Greener program aimed at conserving our natural resources, restoring damaged resources, and creating prosperous communities.

The Westmoreland Conservation District (WCD) seeks funding for conducting on-site wastewater education to the residents of Westmoreland and adjacent counties. This funding will help enable WCD to develop hands-on educational tools and information for the promotion of responsible on-site septic system care and maintenance.

The Alliance for Aquatic Resource Monitoring has limited staff and availability to work with watershed groups and currently only assist about 7 groups a year. Their services revolve around water quality monitoring. With a limited availability to reach and assist groups, ALLARM has determined that a web-based mentor program could assist in reaching more groups. The system will include an online toolbox that will provide groups tutorials that will assist with monitoring protocols, sampling design criteria, and data interpretation.

The Upper West Branch Susquehanna River Conservation Plan identified the restoration of Anderson Creek watershed as a priority in its management recommendations. The newly completed Total Maximum Daily Load (TMDL) study for Anderson Creek has also identified the watershed as severely impacted and provides specific loading reductions for: iron, manganese, aluminum, and acidity concentrations. This project will support the preliminary survey and AMD treatment system for the Smouse Strip, the first source of AMD degradation to an unnamed tributary to Little Anderson Creek.

The Strip Mining Handbook provides citizens an understanding of their rights to monitor and participate in the enforcement of environmental laws. The book provides critical information to landowners dealing with the pressures of and degradation caused by mining.

The Beech Creek Watershed Association (BCWA), in cooperation with state and local agencies, has undertaken a comprehensive watershed restoration project for the Beech Creek watershed, an area highly degraded by abandoned mine drainage. The specific scope of work associated with this project includes: data collection, engineering design, and permitting. The goal of the project is to develop and permit a site plan for construction in a future phase. This will be the first of four phases of the project.

Strong Communities, Healthy Waters: Empowering Farm Communities in the Chesapeake Region is an agricultural initiative working at the watershed level to address Chesapeake Bay water quality. The initiative enhances assistance to farmers who adopt conservation practices. This effort will also advance market-based approaches to managing animal waste and strengthen the economic sustainability of farming communities in threatened watersheds.

Muddy Creek Trout Unlimited is developing a Rivers Conservation Plan for the Muddy Creek watershed. The goal of the project is to collect additional data on wetlands and streams within the watershed in order to identify and prioritize stream reaches and wetlands that should be restored or preserved.

The water quality of Emigh Run is severely impacted by abandoned mine drainage. In order to restore life in the 22 acre Morrisdale Dam, Emigh Run must be remediated as it is the dam’s only water source. The Emigh Run Morrisdale Watershed Association is proposing to design and install a passive treatment system that will abate an abandoned mine discharge named ER-35. Through the completion of a watershed assessment and development of a restoration plan, ER-35 was determined to be Priority Project #5 in the watershed.

The Energy Conservation Council of Pennsylvania board of directors, in support of the Stop the Towers’ effort to stop Allegheny Energy’s Tran Allegheny Interstate Line (TrAIL) and the opposition of NEIT corridor designation, has agreed to affiliate with Stop the Towers in order to promote energy conservation, community outreach/education and support fundraising efforts.
seller_address: 189 Hoge Summit Rd., Eighty Four, PA, 15330

properties.grant_description: Shoup's Run has seen a near miraculous recovery by treating nearly all of the AMD impacts within the watershed. In order to maintain the recovering watershed, the Shoup's Run Watershed Association (SRWA) proposes stockpiling the alkaline martial that is used to treat several of the acidic discharges in the watershed. By stockpiling limestone sand strategically throughout the watershed, SRWA will be able to quickly add the necessary alkalinity needed to prevent any damaging rises in acidity. Additionally, the project will incorporate alkaline addition at the Green Garden's project site.
properties.grant_name: Shoup's Run - Miller Run Alkalinity Addition

properties.grant_description: The purpose of this project is to reduce nutrient and sediment pollution to the Neshannock Creek watershed while providing recreational/educational opportunities to all members of the community with a special focus on disabled veterans and other physically challenged individuals. The completed project will include: an easily maintained sediment and nutrient trap, a 1.5 acre wetland and open water area, a paved nature observation trail, a handicapped preference fishing platform, picnic facilities, and a paved parking area.

Chapter 93 of the PA Code has identified Mill Run as a High Quality Coldwater fishery in the Indian Creek watershed. Mill Run has been suffering from stream bank erosion for many years. This erosion was beginning to widen the stream and diminish the riffle/run/pool habitat critical to a trout fishery. In addition, the riparian areas along the stream have been cut down and mowed over time, removing any root systems that would stabilize the bank and eradicating riparian buffers that cool the water. The silt loading has diminished the number of of aquatic insects and the lack of cover warmed water temperatures, threatening the cold-water species.
The North Area Environmental Council is seeking funding to develop a Rivers Conservation Plan for Pine Creek.

Stream Restoration Incorporated looks to develop a Rivers Conservation Plan for Slippery Rock Creek, a stream that is severely impacted by abandoned mine drainage. This is a two-year project that will server Beaver, Butler, Lawrence, Mercer, and Venango counties. SRI will also work with citizens and local/county planners to address other ecological concerns including urbanization of the I-79 corridor and its impact on prime agricultural lands.

"The Strip Mining Handbook" was published by the Environmental Policy Institute/Friends of the Earth in 1990 as a citizen’s guide for coalfield residents on the 1977 federal law regulating surface coal mining operations. The Handbook has assisted citizens all over the nation’s coalfields in exercising their rights under the federal Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act. With the 30th Anniversary of the federal law having passed last year, and with numerous judicial and regulatory decisions that have affected the law and citizen’s right, an update to the book is long overdue. The Natural Resources Law Center at the University of Colorado Law School is committed to preparing this update and has begun the redrafting of several chapters and is hoping to attract modest support for this effort. It is a vital educational tool that outlines particular provisions of the newly reauthorized Abandoned Mine Land Fund and its SMCRA provisions.

Upstream development has increased storm water flows in Dents Run. Streambank fencing has helped to address sandbar formation and excess sedimentation, but stormwater is still problematic. The goal of this project is to stabilize approximately 400 feet of eroding streambank to protect several streamside structures and install natural stream design devices to control high water flows, dissipate stream energy, and improve habitat.

Mill Creek is a significant tributary to the Allegheny River. Although it is a trout stocked fishery, much of the upper watershed is impaired by excessive nutrients. The stream crosses the Allegheny River Recreational Trail near its mouth. Camping, fishing, and unrestricted ATV use of the area near the mouth have resulted in severe streambank instability and excessive erosion increasing the sediment deposition into Mill Creek.

Cedar Run is an urban watershed that supports a naturally reproducing brown trout fishery. This project aims to alert homeowners and businesses on how their actions impact this fragile ecosystem. The Alliance seeks to facilitate the installation of at least three stormwater retrofit projects that will not only manage stormwater flow, but also provide demonstration sites that will help improve the general acceptance of natural stormwater control.

This project will relocate 220 linear feet of headwaters on Bear Loop Run. This stream segment courses through an abandoned strip mine cut, which severely degrades the water quality and negatively impacts fish populations. The project is also expected to reduce down-slope mine seeps.

The purpose of this project is to improve the Tangascootack Site #1 treatment system. The original design principles of the system did not adequately address treatment needs and allows acidic water to flow into the South Fork of the Tangascootack.

The Espy Run watershed is heavily impacted by abandoned mine drainage (AMD). Portions of the creek disappear into underground boreholes, leaving the channel dry. When water flow resurfaces further down the channel, it is heavily impacted by AMD and is devoid of aquatic life. The existing passive treatment system installed at the Espy Run seep was constructed in 1996 and does not treat the entire discharge. This project will improve water quality by treating the entire discharge.

Over the past five years, the Coldwater Heritage Partnership has funded 51 Coldwater Conservation Plans. The initial investment of approximately $250000 in Coldwater Conservation Grants has helped leverage well over $2000000 in additional projects. This year's awards will support the development of Coldwater Conservation Plans for Clark Creek (Dauphin County), Coplay Creek (Lehigh County), Headwaters of Fishing Creek (Columbia and Sullivan Counties), Hokendauqua Creek (Northampton County), Larry's Creek (Lycoming County), Little Paint Creek (Somerset County), and Willow Run (Juniata County).

The ultimate goal of the Emigh Run Lakeside Watershed Association is to restore Hubler Run to a trout fishery. The current Hubler 1 passive treatment system needs retrofitted to improve system performance during high-flow conditions. This rehabilitation project, combined with the Hubler 2 construction project and the Hubler Run 3 feasibility study will address three sources of abandoned mine drainage to Hubler Run.
These funds will be used to help defray the litigation costs for the Energy Conservation Council’s opposition to Allegheny Energy’s TrAIL Project.
seller_address: 189 Hoge Summit Rd., Eighty Four, PA, 15330

properties.grant_description: The Anthracite Coal Region has a multitude of detailed mine maps that are inventoried and in good shape. Despite the state’s efforts to develop a State Water Plan, mine pools are poorly understood and their overall value has not been assessed. With advancements in technology, the Eastern PA Coalition for Abandoned Mine Reclamation proposes to digitize existing mine maps, correlating geology, hydrology, and water chemistry to estimate the total water resource available in underground mine complexes.

When a dam was removed from Wolf Creek in 2005, the previously trapped sediment began making its way downstream. The transported sediment formed gravel bars and altered flow patterns. This project aims to remove excess sediment, stabilize eroded banks, and develop healthy riparian buffers.

Natural Biodiversity seeks funding to develop and demonstrate prioritized invasive plant and noxious weed management on riparian lands within the most precious and vulnerable areas in the Juniata watershed. This project will systematically identify priority prevention and rapid response areas, management strategies, and will demonstrate exemplary management regarding weed problems in riparian forest buffers.

On behalf of the Chesapeake Bay Watershed Coalition’s “Chose Clean Water” Campaign, the Nation Wildlife Federation seeks funding to support efforts to build a coalition comprised of non-governmental organizations to restore and protect the Chesapeake Bay through federal advocacy and accountability, and action at the state and local levels.

The Big Spring Run Floodplain Restoration Project will restore the floodplain along 3850 feet of the stream by removing legacy sediment that has accumulated over the past 150 years due to a downstream mill dam. Streambank erosion will be significantly reduced with this restoration, resulting in reduced nutrient and sediment loads delivered to the Conestoga River watershed.

The PA Land Trust Association (PALTA) seeks funding to support its national and state level efforts to prevent the construction of interstate transmission lines that would increase production and emissions from coal-fired power plants. Specifically, PALTA will monitor the electric industry, gather, analyze and disseminate relevant data to allies, and facilitate communications among those working to stop coal-fired transmission expansion.

The Schuylkill Headwaters Association (SHA) is seeking funds to hire two Office of Surface Mining VISTA members. The first position will focus his efforts on issues within the Schuylkill River Watershed. The second position will focus her efforts on assisting five other watershed groups covering the remainder of the county. One of the important functions of the VISTA positions is to complete inventories of acid mine drainage seeps by doing stream walks. This valuable function is the first step in watershed restoration and the access of funding from the Office of Surface Mining, administered through PA's Bureau of Abandoned Mine Reclamation office.

The primary goal of this project is to reduce the iron deposition from the Woodville discharge to Chartiers Creek. This will eliminate a highly visible iron scar and substantially decrease degradation of the Chartiers Creek backchannel and main stem. The discharge is easily accessible making it a prime location for high school and college tours that highlight AMD pollution. Once completed, interpretive signage will provide groups with a more complete educational experience.
The purpose of this distribution is for the statewide public opinion survey consultant fee.

To address critical watershed issues, the Westmoreland Conservation District (WCD) is proposing to create a family of new education materials for landowners regarding on-lot septic management, private water sources, and pond management. WCD intends to produce and begin distributing these materials in the next few months so that they are available to address the immediate needs in the county. WCD will also begin the process of updating their highly successful and well used bioinfiltration poster and undertake a strategic discussion with key members of the community to identify longer-term needs and fixes in these critical watershed areas.

The Blair County Conservation District seeks funding for the Cove Cover Crop Conference. This event is aimed at promoting cover cropping as a choice practice needed in the Cove area watershed. These funds will cover the costs of a pre-conference meeting that will connect conference speakers, partners, and organizers to members of the water authority, municipality officials, and other land/water community decision makers.

The Brownsville Area Revitalization Corps (BARC) seeks funding to develop a grant application to the DCNR Community Conservation Partnerships Program to match the cost to print water trail maps. The water trail project will serve as the catalyst to foster a permanent watershed group that will oversee the protection and restoration of the Middle Monongahela River.
seller_address: PO Box 97, 69 Market St., Brownsville, PA, 15417

properties.grant_description: The Capital Resource Conservation and Development Area Council seeks funding to provide administration and project planning/implementation costs to four short-term projects. These funds will be used to cover the costs of bringing together and working with the project partners to: 1) plan and implement viable solutions to land conservation strategies in the southwest portion of Cumberland, Franklin, Adams, and York counties; 2) demonstrate water harvesting strategies through technical assistance in the set-up and maintenance of rain barrels and other appropriate practices for homeowners in Cumberland/Franklin county watersheds; 3) provide technical guidance to landowners for planting/maintaining native riparian buffers; and 4) to support/demonstrate the connections between agricultural land preservation efforts and the marketing/growth of interest in local fresh food products in the regions.

During the 2008 Regional Conservancy Roundatable Event, the conservancies collaborated on solutions for needs within their own organizations that could assist them in their efforts. One of the the overarching items for all was a general need to inform and influence the general "marketing" of land protection as an integral part of local economic development and compatible growth in the region.  To that end, the Central Pennsylvania Conservancy seeks funding to hold a training workshop focused on "crafting and sending a common message" through website and networking tools.

The City of Johnstown seeks funding to determine the feasibility of using the abandoned mine drainage from the Inclined Plane site for pretreatment use in ground source heat exchange. Specifically, these funds will be used to: determine the sustainable mine flow capacity, assess existing infrastructure beneath the city, determine available BTUs for heating/cooling capacities, and developing costs for implementation.
These funds will support a teacher workshop on alternative energy issues to be held at Huntingdon Farm.

The Eastern PA Coalition for Abandoned Mine Reclamation seeks funding to offset the costs of a Request for Qualifications document preparation and development of a Technical Assistance Review Committee for the Shamokin Creek watershed and an AMD treatment feasibility study for industrial development.
The Forum for Pennsylvania’s Heartland seeks funding to help underwrite the cost of the Susquehanna River Heartland Coalition for Environmental Studies’ annual report, “Pulse of the Heartland 2009.”
These funds will cover the costs of the Foundation of Pennsylvania Watersheds membership dues to the Grantmakers of Western Pennsylvania.

The Juniata Clean Water Partnership seeks funding to support its 9th Annual Juniata River Sojourn, a five day event that incorporates resource awareness, watershed education, and appreciation for the beauty and wildlife in the Juniata watershed.

The Keystone Conservation Trust seeks funding to help non-profit organizations reach qualified donors and explain how they can sell their real estate and donate money to conservation at the same time.
seller_address: 336 King of Prussia Rd., Radnor, PA, 19087

properties.grant_description: The Kiski-Conemaugh Stream Team seeks funding to support the activities associated with Outdoor Heritage Month, including Outdoor Adventures.

The Lake Erie-Allegheny Earth Force seeks funding to support travel and venue costs associated with hosting its Youth Summits.
